'''Punalu'u Black Sand Beach''' is a beach near [[Naalehu, Hawaii]] on the [[Hawaii (island)|Big Island]] of [[Hawaii]] that has black sand created by volcanic activity. The volcanic activity is now in [[Hawaii Volcanoes National Park]]. Taking black sand is prohibited, but ''local tradition'' says that if any of the black sand from Punalu'u beach is taken away from [[Hawaii]] that the person that took it will be cursed until it is returned. The same is said about the local volcanic rocks.
Camping is permitted at Punalu'u Black Sand Beach Park, though in recent years the campground has been patronized by those wishing to engage in more tomfoolery (and sometimes disruption of the habits of the [[sea turtles]] that frequent Punalu'u) than recreation, making the park difficult to enjoy on the weekends.

'''Punalu'u Black Sand Beach''' is a beach near [[Naalehu, Hawaii]] on the [[Hawaii (island)|Big Island]] of [[Hawaii]] that has black sand created by volcanic activity. This occurs when the lava flows into the ocean and explodes when it cools as it hits the ocean. The volcanic activity is now in [[Hawaii Volcanoes National Park]]. Taking black sand is prohibited, but, like volcanic rocks, local tradition says that if any of the black sand from Punalu'u Beach is taken away from Hawaii that the person that took it will be cursed until it is returned. Camping is permitted at Punalu'u Black Sand Beach Park.
The swimming area is very rocky, and it can be dangerous to swim. Also the beach has a large amount of underground fresh water that flows in it. This fresh water is very cold and looks almost like gasoline mixing with the water. Legend has it that in the time of drought, the early Hawaiians living in the area would dive underwater with a jug to get their fresh water.
Punalu'u is frequented by large [[Green Sea Turtle]]s, which can often be seen basking on the black sand. Visitors must remain 15 feet from the turtles at all times.
[[Category:Geography of Hawaii]] [[Category:Geography of Hawaii|Punaluu Black Sand Beach]]
{{Hawaii-geo-stub}}

[[Image:Punaluu_Black_Sand_Beach.JPG|right|thumb|300px|Punalu'u Black Sand Beach <small>(Photo: [http://kenya.allmond.us Kenya Allmond])</small>]] [[Image:Punaluu turtle.jpg|right|thumb|300px|A Sea Turtle resting on Punalu'u Black Sand Beach <small>(Photo: [http://www.andhawaii.com/big-island/punaluu_beach.html Lisa Weber])</small>]]
'''Punalu'u Black Sand Beach''' is a beach near [[Naalehu, Hawaii]] on the [[Hawaii (island)|Big Island]] of [[Hawaii]] that has [[black sand]] created by volcanic activity. This occurs when the lava flows into the ocean and explodes when it cools as it hits the ocean. The volcanic activity is now in [[Hawaii Volcanoes National Park]].
Punalu'u is frequented by large [[Green Sea Turtle]]s, which can often be seen basking on the black sand. Visitors must remain 15 feet from the turtles at all times.
Taking black sand is prohibited but, as with volcanic rocks, local tradition says that if any of the black sand from Punalu'u Beach is taken away from Hawaii that the person that took it will be cursed until it is returned. Camping is permitted at Punalu'u Black Sand Beach Park, though in recent years the campground has been patronized by disorderly visitors known for bothering the [[sea turtles]] that frequent Punalu'u), making the park difficult to enjoy on the weekends.
The swimming area is very rocky, and it can be dangerous to swim. Also the beach has a large amount of underground fresh water that flows in it. This fresh water is very cold and looks almost like gasoline mixing with the water. Legend has it that in the time of drought, the early Hawaiians living in the area would dive underwater with a jug to get their fresh water.
==Development==
There has been recent controversy in the area because of a proposed redevelopment of the decaying infrastructure. Sea Mountain V hopes to bring new jobs, new job training, and a partnership with [[Jean-Michel Cousteau]]'s Ocean Futures Society [http://www.oceanfutures.org] for marine and land protection programs. Most Punalu'u residents support this project due to the dire need to bring a new economic driver to the area, which began to decline with the closing of the sugar plantations in the 1980s and 90s. Sea Mountain at Punaluu will create an environmentally sensitive complex committed to economic revitalization for the people of Ka, and the environmental protection for the land and ocean.
This renewed vision of Sea Mountain complex will revitalize the current deteriorated, dilapidated infrastructure at Punaluu, refreshing and enhancing the 434-acre area between Pahala and Naalehu that currently is home to rotting buildings and failing infrastructure, including the 30-year-old sewer system that is "marginally adequate" according to recent assessments and the inadequate water system that serves more than 100 households at Punaluu. In addition, the project is expected to bring 517 permanent, new jobs to the area, as well as create $735 million in economic input and $342 million in new household income for this area in desperate need of assistance, where most people spend between four and seven hours a day in transit to find work in Kona or Hilo.
Sea Mountain V also has offered to donate land to create a 17-acre park, as well as create a Shoreline Preservation Area that will Deed Restrict the designated shoreline area so no buildings will be allowed in the shoreline area except those shown on the shoreline plan, preserving the shoreline forever. This area will encompass approximately 56 acres of shoreline.
Through collaborative conversations with the community in 2005 and 2006, the revised development is scaled significantly back from the original proposal. Todays development calls for 1,400 units total (combined hotel and residential) with no more than 350 of those units being hotel units spread over a 434-acre area. One of those hotels will be a small, eco-hotel with [[Jean-Michel Cousteau]]. All buildings will be pushed far back from the shoreline, between 300 and 600 feet off the beach. New entry points will be added to the ocean, to enhance the local residents ability to access the ocean that is so integral to life in the area. New public amenities will be built for the local residents, including a refurbished boat dock, restrooms, and walking trails. In addition, the developer is working with community to create a Cultural Center for the region of Ka, as well as a Community Benefits Package, that would provide millions of dollars to the community over the life of the project. This money would benefit the hospital, the schools and other local institutions or groups that work to benefit the community.
Because of the partnership with [[Jean-Michel Cousteau]] and Ocean Futures Society, the development will bring new programs for the children of the Punaluu, including [[Jean-Michel Cousteau]]s famous Ambassadors of the Environment program, which provides students from 7 17 a chance to learn more about the local environment and ways to conserve this precious resource. Ocean Futures Society has offered to present ongoing educational lectures and seminars at Ka High School as well. With Ocean Futures Society, the development will ensure the project is good for Hawaiis environment. [[Jean-Michel Cousteau]] embarked on a similar program in Fiji, which Conde Nast Travel Magazine named the Jean-Michel Cousteau Fiji Island Resort as the top eco-resort in the world in 2005. [[Jean-Michel Cousteau]] has developed protection projects for sustainable reefs in America Samoa, and hopes to establish a similar program at Sea Mountain at Punaluu. For example, his Ocean Futures Society hopes to develop a protection program for the Hawaiian green sea turtle and the Hawksbill turtle, to help these animals flourish. By creating marine preservation programs, [[Jean-Michel Cousteau]] and Ocean Futures Society will be able to attract world-class marine scientists to help study and preserve the ocean as it was.

[[Image:Punaluu_Black_Sand_Beach.JPG|right|thumb|300px|Punalu{{okina}}u Black Sand Beach <small>(Photo: [http://kenya.allmond.us Kenya Allmond])</small>]] [[Image:Punaluu turtle.jpg|right|thumb|300px|A Sea Turtle resting on Punalu{{okina}}u Black Sand Beach <small>(Photo: [http://www.andhawaii.com/big-island/punaluu_beach.html Lisa Weber])</small>]]
'''Punalu{{okina}}u Black Sand Beach''' is a beach near [[N'lehu, Hawai'i|N{{okina}}lehu]] on the [[Hawaii (island)|Big Island]] of the [[U.S. state]] of [[Hawaii|Hawai{{okina}}i]] that has [[black sand]] created by volcanic activity. This occurs when the lava flows into the ocean and explodes when it cools as it hits the ocean. The volcanic activity is now in [[Hawaii Volcanoes National Park|Hawai{{okina}}i Volcanoes National Park]].
Punalu{{okina}}u is frequented by large [[Green Sea Turtle]]s, which can often be seen basking on the black sand. Visitors must remain 15 feet from the turtles at all times. The swimming area is very rocky, and it can be dangerous to swim.
Taking black sand is prohibited but, as with volcanic rocks, local tradition says that if any of the black sand from Punalu{{okina}}u Beach is taken away from Hawai{{okina}}i that the person that took it will be cursed until it is returned. Camping is permitted at Punalu{{okina}}u Black Sand Beach Park.
The beach has a large amount of underground fresh water that flows in it. This fresh water is very cold and looks almost like gasoline mixing with the water. Legend has it that in the time of drought, the early Hawaiians living in the area would dive underwater with a jug to get their fresh water.
==Wahi Pana O Punalu'u: The Sacred Sites of Punalu`u==
Punalu`u and adjacent areas provide evidence of the shifts in use of sacred space over time. Monumental architecture in the form of large heiau complexes (ritual centers) speak to the power of na ali`i (the Chiefs) and the social stratification of Ka`us ancient feudal society. With the advent of Missionaries arriving in the district as early as 1833, Christianity left its distinct architectural hallmark on the landscape of Ka`u. Sitting high on the ridge above Punalu`u is the Opukahaia Memorial Chapel and graveyard built on the birthplace of Henry Opukahala (1792-1818) who inspired the missionary movement that forever changed Hawai`i.
There are three pre-contact heiau within the immediate vicinity of Punalu`u. The walled heiau was introduced to Hawaii about A.D. 1100 and Punalu`u is one of the last places in Hawaii where one can enjoy an unaltered view from one heiau to the next.
To the south lies Ka`ie`ie Heiau. Thought to be a fishing shrine the heiau was built on a prominent bluff overlooking the ocean to the south, what were once the Ninole fishponds to the west and Koloa Bay to the east - home of the legendary na `ili`ili hanau (birthing stones) said to have supernatural ability to propagate. These smooth, water-polished stones were highly desired and were used for paving heiau, for arming slingshots and as game pieces for the Hawaiian game konane. The name Ka`ie`ie is thought to refer to a type of fishing trap or weir made of the fibrous `ie`ie vine. Considered, to be in good condition by early surveyors, several walls and a raised stone platform are all that remain of Ka`ie`ie today. Recent scholarship has interpreted the site as multi-functional. It likely served as a place of offerings and tributes, an observation point for monitoring the fishponds as well as a communications relay and dissemination location.
The heiau complex of Lanipau has not faired as well. Heavily impacted by the construction of the Sea Mountain Resort golf course. Once the largest of the three, today what remains of Lanipau is in essence an island swallowed up by a sea of putting and driving greens.
The heiau complex that sits overlooking the ocean and Punalu`u Beach is referred to by many names including, Halelau, Kane`ele`ele; Mailekini or Punalu`u Nui. This hieau, likely extended to the edge of the cliff at Punalu`u Bay. Its westernmost boundary was destroyed to make way for the construction of a wharf/warehouse complex for the sugar company in 1906. Identified as a heiau luakini (human sacrafice temple), a large table-like stone rests outside the southernmost wall and is known locally as Pohaku Mohai (sacrificial stone). Early site surveys noted possible kauhale (houses) adjacent to the heiau that were likely the residences of na kahuna (religious specialists).
Another important cultural feature is ala kahakai (trail by the sea) that served as an important link between ritual centers and coastal communities. A path with divine origins, the ala kahakai was thought to be the original route taken by the God Lono from North Kohala to the southernmost tip of the island and then windward along the Ka`u coast to Puna. This trail once paved with the `ili`ili hanau, (birthing stones) was designated as a National Historic Trail by President Clinton in 2000 and remnants can be found at both Punalu`u Nui and Ka`ie`ie heiau.
Kii pohaku (petroglyphs) can be found near the County Park Pavilions within a protected area surrounded by a rock wall just past the parking area. It is easy to miss these unmarked ancient carvings.
Please kokua: While visiting Hawaiian wahi pana or sacred spaces please keep in mind that many wahi pana are still being used today by native Hawaiians. Treat them with the reverence due any sacred site modern or ancient.
==Development==
There is an ongoing discussion of a proposed redevelopment of the infrastructure currently serving Punalu{{okina}}u. Sea Mountain V hopes to bring new jobs, new job training, and a partnership with [[Jean-Michel Cousteau]]'s Ocean Futures Society [http://www.oceanfutures.org] for marine and land protection programs.
Sea Mountain V has stated that the complex will be environmentally friendly, and that the proposed Sea Mountain complex will renew the current infrastructure at Punalu{{okina}}u, enhancing the area between Pahala and N{{okina}}lehu. Sea Mountain V has also offered to donate land to create a 17-acre park, as well as create a shoreline preservation area that will restrict the designated shoreline area so no buildings will be allowed except those shown on the shoreline plan.
Some people in the Punalu{{okina}}u area support this project due to the desire to bring a new economic driver to the area, which began to decline with the closing of the sugar plantations in the 1980s and 90s. However, others in the area oppose this project becuase they believe that it will significantly damage the environment.
Through collaborative conversations with the community in 2005 and 2006, the revised development is scaled significantly back from the original proposal. Todays development calls for 1,400 total hotel and residential units spread over a 434-acre area. All buildings will be pushed far back from the shoreline, between 300 and 600 feet off the beach. In addition, the developer is working with community to create a Cultural Center for the region of Ka{{okina}}.

==Endangered Species== Rare and endangered native animals known at Punalu`u and Ninole are the honu ea and honu, Hawaiian monk seal, native bees, orange-black damselfly, and other anchialine pond fauna. Native birds are seen near the shore and cliffs or fly over the area on their way to the sea from upland nesting colonies, including the endangered Hawaiian hawk ('io) that nests in the trees at Punalu`u. The reconnaissance survey team observed spinner dolphins and humpback whales offshore from Punaluu. Residents say such sightings are common. A rare sighting of a Hawaiian monk seal was reported at Punalu`u in Sept. of 2006 near the boat ramp, and several known nesting sites of the endangered honu ea are located along the Punalu`u and Ninole area. Such occurrences indicate a healthy environment with adequate resources to support large marine animals
The honu ea (Eretmochelys imbricate) is a federally listed endangered species and is the rarest sea turtle in the Pacific Ocean. In the Hawaiian Islands, more than 90% of honu ea nests are found on the Big Island. Researchers estimate there are fewer than 80 nesting honu ea in the Hawaiian islands, of which 67 nest on the island of Hawaii. More than half of the known nesting population statewide, 40 individuals nest along the southeast boundary of Hawaii Volcanoes National park to Waikapuna. The shoreline should be considered a critical and ecologically significant nesting coastline for honu ea.
The threatened green sea turtle or honu (Chelonia mydas) feeds on marine plants in shallow waters along the coastline. Punaluu is an especially well known site for honu. Red seaweed, a favorite food of the honu flourishes on the coral-encrusted rocks in the shallow waters of the bay and the turtles are found basking on the black sand beach despite the presence of beachgoers. Researchers with the National Marine Fisheries have been studying the honu at Punaluu since 1982 along with groups of Hawaii students.
The endangered Hawaiian Hoary Bat , opeapea, (Lasirus cinereus semotus), is known to fly over and reside at Punalu`u. The hoary bat's habitat stretches from sea level to over 13,000 feet It usually weighs about 5 to 8 ounces, is nocturnal and feeds on insects. Relatively little research has been done on this endemic Hawaiian bat and data regarding its habitat and population status is very limited.
One of the largest populations of the rare orange-black damselfly (Megalagrion xanthomelas) can be found at Ninole. It is a candidate endangered species and thrives in the aquatic habitat of the extensive spring complex that stretches from Nnole Springs to the estuary at Honuapo. Systematic surveys have observed damselfly populations at Kwa, Hlea, Nnole, and Honuapo. The highest densities occur at the back of estuarine marshes, at the mouth of Hlea and Nnole Streams, and at Kwa Springs.
==Vegetation== The native plant communities generally appear as a narrow strand of vegetation, mostly a flattened growth of various shrubs, vines, grass-like plants, scattered trees and herbs. The varied habitats of phoehoe (smooth, ropy lava), and a flats, drifted sand, anchialine pond shores, protected beaches, and sea spray battered bluffs each support different native plant communities. In the reconnaissance survey, fourteen species of coastal strand plants (six trees, seven ground cover or shrubforms and the invasive aquatic water hyacinth. Native plants such as naupaka kahakai, ilima ku kahakai, and phuehue. were found in the area.
==Pools, Ponds, and Estuaries== The second largest spring complex on Hawaii Island is located at Punaluu and Ninole Cove. Stretching from Punalu`u to Nnole Springs through Kwa to Honuapo, is a series of wetlands fed by basal springs and intermittent streams that support a broad range of native fauna. These spring and pool complexes contain individuals, particularly juveniles or recruits, of several marine invertebrates and fishes, suggesting it may be a significant refuge or nursery area for nearshore marine fauna on the southern coast of Hawaii Island.
==Punalu`us Anchialine Ponds== Anchialine (near the sea) pools of various types occur near and around Punalu`u and Ninole Cove. These pools are rare and localized brackish waters along coastal lava flows that exhibit tidal fluctuations without a surface connection to the sea. They include open pools near the shore as well as undisturbed pools in collapsed lava tubes, cracks, and caves. Endemic and native shrimp species live in pools and travel between and through them through underground cracks. The orange-black damselfly breeds in the anchialine pools while native insects perch on the nearby vegetation. Throughout the state, anchialine species are severely threatened by alien insects, by habitat loss due to coastal development, and by other human impacts.
Anchialine ponds are one of Hawaiis most threatened ecosystems. Anchialine pools are landlocked brackish ponds located close to the shoreline connected to the ocean via subterranean tunnels. Characterized by tidal fluctuations, these rare and fragile ponds are home to unusual plants and animals.
In the U.S., this habitat exists only in the Hawaiian Islands and, of the approximately 700 known anchialine pools, the majority are located on the island of Hawaii. Formed by volcanic activity, these pools are home to a unique assemblage of invertebrate and algal species, some of which are known to exist only in this habitat. In the last 20 years, alien fish species have been introduced and/or invaded a majority of the pools. These alien species have gradually destroyed the ecological balance in many of the pools by eliminating many of unique endemic species.
==Koa Fish Houses== Punalu`u has long been know for its koa (fish houses) where specific species of fish live in specific areas offshore. The pristine, spring fed waters of Punalu`u mixing with the salt water of the ocean provide ideal habitat for a variety of fish that live in these naturally created koa. There are several koa just offshore from Punalu`u still used by local fishermen. Each koa is identified by the species of fish that live there, including yellow fin tuna and mackerel. In the old days, Hawaiian families would feed the fish in the koa cooked taro and pumpkin and the fish in return, would provide a constant source of protien.
==Ownership of Ponds== The Civil Code of the Hawaiian kingdom did not allow the sale of fishponds or wetlands as these were resources of the common people. After 1850, when the Hawaiian government began selling land, the Privy Council refused to permit any fishponds to be sold. They were all reserved for the government, to be used by the people.

==Wahi Pana O Punalu'u: The Sacred Sites of Punalu`u==
Punalu`u and adjacent areas provide evidence of the shifts in use of sacred space over time. Considered, to be in good condition by early surveyors, several walls and a raised stone platform are all that remain of Ka`ie`ie today. It likely served as a place of offerings and tributes, an observation point for monitoring the fishponds as well as a communications relay and dissemination location.

This hieau, likely extended to the edge of the cliff at Punalu`u Bay. Its westernmost boundary was destroyed to make way for the construction of a wharf/warehouse complex for the sugar company in 1906. Identified as a heiau luakini (human sacrafice temple), a large table-like stone rests outside the southernmost wall and is known locally as Pohaku Mohai (sacrificial stone). Early site surveys noted possible kauhale (houses) adjacent to the heiau that were likely the residences of na kahuna (religious specialists).
Another important cultural feature is ala kahakai (trail by the sea) that served as an important link between ritual centers and coastal communities. ==Endangered Species== Rare and endangered native animals known at Punalu`u and Ninole are the honu ea and honu, Hawaiian monk seal, native bees, orange-black damselfly, and other anchialine pond fauna. Native birds are seen near the shore and cliffs or fly over the area on their way to the sea from upland nesting colonies, including the endangered Hawaiian hawk ('io) that nests in the trees at Punalu`u. The reconnaissance survey team observed spinner dolphins and humpback whales offshore from Punaluu. Residents say such sightings are common. A rare sighting of a Hawaiian monk seal was reported at Punalu`u in Sept. of 2006 near the boat ramp, and several known nesting sites of the endangered honu ea are located along the Punalu`u and Ninole area. Such occurrences indicate a healthy environment with adequate resources to support large marine animals
The honu ea (Eretmochelys imbricate) is a federally listed endangered species and is the rarest sea turtle in the Pacific Ocean. In the Hawaiian Islands, more than 90% of honu ea nests are found on the Big Island. Researchers estimate there are fewer than 80 nesting honu ea in the Hawaiian islands, of which 67 nest on the island of Hawaii. More than half of the known nesting population statewide, 40 individuals nest along the southeast boundary of Hawaii Volcanoes National park to Waikapuna. The shoreline should be considered a critical and ecologically significant nesting coastline for honu ea.
The threatened green sea turtle or honu (Chelonia mydas) feeds on marine plants in shallow waters along the coastline. Punaluu is an especially well known site for honu. Red seaweed, a favorite food of the honu flourishes on the coral-encrusted rocks in the shallow waters of the bay and the turtles are found basking on the black sand beach despite the presence of beachgoers. Researchers with the National Marine Fisheries have been studying the honu at Punaluu since 1982 along with groups of Hawaii students.
The endangered Hawaiian Hoary Bat , opeapea, (Lasirus cinereus semotus), is known to fly over and reside at Punalu`u. The hoary bat's habitat stretches from sea level to over 13,000 feet It usually weighs about 5 to 8 ounces, is nocturnal and feeds on insects. Relatively little research has been done on this endemic Hawaiian bat and data regarding its habitat and population status is very limited.
One of the largest populations of the rare orange-black damselfly (Megalagrion xanthomelas) can be found at Ninole. It is a candidate endangered species and thrives in the aquatic habitat of the extensive spring complex that stretches from Nnole Springs to the estuary at Honuapo. Systematic surveys have observed damselfly populations at Kwa, Hlea, Nnole, and Honuapo. The highest densities occur at the back of estuarine marshes, at the mouth of Hlea and Nnole Streams, and at Kwa Springs.
==Vegetation== The native plant communities generally appear as a narrow strand of vegetation, mostly a flattened growth of various shrubs, vines, grass-like plants, scattered trees and herbs. The varied habitats of phoehoe (smooth, ropy lava), and a flats, drifted sand, anchialine pond shores, protected beaches, and sea spray battered bluffs each support different native plant communities. In the reconnaissance survey, fourteen species of coastal strand plants (six trees, seven ground cover or shrubforms and the invasive aquatic water hyacinth. Native plants such as naupaka kahakai, ilima ku kahakai, and phuehue. were found in the area.
==Pools, Ponds, and Estuaries== The second largest spring complex on Hawaii Island is located at Punaluu and Ninole Cove. Stretching from Punalu`u to Nnole Springs through Kwa to Honuapo, is a series of wetlands fed by basal springs and intermittent streams that support a broad range of native fauna. These spring and pool complexes contain individuals, particularly juveniles or recruits, of several marine invertebrates and fishes, suggesting it may be a significant refuge or nursery area for nearshore marine fauna on the southern coast of Hawaii Island.
==Punalu`us Anchialine Ponds== Anchialine (near the sea) pools of various types occur near and around Punalu`u and Ninole Cove. These pools are rare and localized brackish waters along coastal lava flows that exhibit tidal fluctuations without a surface connection to the sea. They include open pools near the shore as well as undisturbed pools in collapsed lava tubes, cracks, and caves. Endemic and native shrimp species live in pools and travel between and through them through underground cracks. The orange-black damselfly breeds in the anchialine pools while native insects perch on the nearby vegetation. Throughout the state, anchialine species are severely threatened by alien insects, by habitat loss due to coastal development, and by other human impacts.
Anchialine ponds are one of Hawaiis most threatened ecosystems. Anchialine pools are landlocked brackish ponds located close to the shoreline connected to the ocean via subterranean tunnels. Characterized by tidal fluctuations, these rare and fragile ponds are home to unusual plants and animals.
In the U.S., this habitat exists only in the Hawaiian Islands and, of the approximately 700 known anchialine pools, the majority are located on the island of Hawaii. Formed by volcanic activity, these pools are home to a unique assemblage of invertebrate and algal species, some of which are known to exist only in this habitat. In the last 20 years, alien fish species have been introduced and/or invaded a majority of the pools. These alien species have gradually destroyed the ecological balance in many of the pools by eliminating many of unique endemic species.
==Koa Fish Houses== Punalu`u has long been know for its koa (fish houses) where specific species of fish live in specific areas offshore. The pristine, spring fed waters of Punalu`u mixing with the salt water of the ocean provide ideal habitat for a variety of fish that live in these naturally created koa. There are several koa just offshore from Punalu`u still used by local fishermen. Each koa is identified by the species of fish that live there, including yellow fin tuna and mackerel. In the old days, Hawaiian families would feed the fish in the koa cooked taro and pumpkin and the fish in return, would provide a constant source of protien.
==Ownership of Ponds== The Civil Code of the Hawaiian kingdom did not allow the sale of fishponds or wetlands as these were resources of the common people. After 1850, when the Hawaiian government began selling land, the Privy Council refused to permit any fishponds to be sold. They were all reserved for the government, to be used by the people.
==Development==
There is an ongoing discussion of a proposed redevelopment of the infrastructure currently serving Punalu{{okina}}u. Sea Mountain V hopes to bring new jobs, new job training, and a partnership with [[Jean-Michel Cousteau]]'s Ocean Futures Society [http://www.oceanfutures.org] for marine and land protection programs.
Sea Mountain V has stated that the complex will be environmentally friendly, and that the proposed Sea Mountain complex will renew the current infrastructure at Punalu{{okina}}u, enhancing the area between Pahala and N{{okina}}lehu. Sea Mountain V has also offered to donate land to create a 17-acre park, as well as create a shoreline preservation area that will restrict the designated shoreline area so no buildings will be allowed except those shown on the shoreline plan.
Some people in the Punalu{{okina}}u area support this project due to the desire to bring a new economic driver to the area, which began to decline with the closing of the sugar plantations in the 1980s and 90s. However, others in the area oppose this project becuase they believe that it will significantly damage the environment.
Through collaborative conversations with the community in 2005 and 2006, the revised development is scaled significantly back from the original proposal. Todays development calls for 1,400 total hotel and residential units spread over a 434-acre area. All buildings will be pushed far back from the shoreline, between 300 and 600 feet off the beach. In addition, the developer is working with community to create a Cultural Center for the region of Ka{{okina}}.

In the reconnaissance survey, fourteen species of coastal strand plants (six trees, seven ground cover or shrubforms and the invasive aquatic water hyacinth. Native plants such as naupaka kahakai, ilima ku kahakai, and phuehue. were found in the area.

==Development==
There is an ongoing discussion of a proposed redevelopment of the infrastructure currently serving Punalu{{okina}}u. Sea Mountain V hopes to bring new jobs, new job training, and a partnership with [[Jean-Michel Cousteau]]'s Ocean Futures Society [http://www.oceanfutures.org] for marine and land protection programs.
Sea Mountain V has stated that the complex will be environmentally friendly, and that the proposed Sea Mountain complex will renew the current infrastructure at Punalu{{okina}}u, enhancing the area between Pahala and N{{okina}}lehu. Sea Mountain V has also offered to donate land to create a 17-acre park, as well as create a shoreline preservation area that will restrict the designated shoreline area so no buildings will be allowed except those shown on the shoreline plan.

However, others in the area oppose this project becuase they believe that it will significantly damage the environment.
Through collaborative conversations with the community in 2005 and 2006, the revised development is scaled significantly back from the original proposal. Todays development calls for 1,400 total hotel and residential units spread over a 434-acre area. All buildings will be pushed far back from the shoreline, between 300 and 600 feet off the beach. In addition, the developer is working with community to create a Cultural Center for the region of Ka{{okina}}.

More than half of the known nesting population statewide, 40 individuals nest along the southeast boundary of Hawaii Volcanoes National park to Waikapuna. The shoreline should be considered a critical and ecologically significant nesting coastline for honu ea.
The threatened [[green sea turtle]] or honu (Chelonia mydas) feeds on marine plants in shallow waters along the coastline. Punaluu is an especially well known site for honu. Red seaweed, a favorite food of the honu flourishes on the coral-encrusted rocks in the shallow waters of the bay and the turtles are found basking on the black sand beach despite the presence of beachgoers. Researchers with the National Marine Fisheries have been studying the honu at Punaluu since 1982 along with groups of Hawaii students.
The endangered [[Hawaiian Hoary Bat]], opeapea, (Lasirus cinereus semotus), is known to fly over and reside at Punalu`u. The [[Hawaiian Hoary Bat]]s habitat stretches from sea level to over 13,000 feet It usually weighs about 5 to 8 ounces, is nocturnal and feeds on insects. Relatively little research has been done on this endemic Hawaiian bat and data regarding its habitat and population status is very limited.
One of the largest populations of the rare orange-black damselfly (Megalagrion xanthomelas) can be found at Ninole. It is a candidate endangered species and thrives in the aquatic habitat of the extensive spring complex that stretches from Nnole Springs to the estuary at Honuapo. Systematic surveys have observed damselfly populations at Kwa, Hlea, Nnole, and Honuapo. The highest densities occur at the back of estuarine marshes, at the mouth of Hlea and Nnole Streams, and at Kwa Springs.
==Vegetation== The native plant communities generally appear as a narrow strand of vegetation, mostly a flattened growth of various shrubs, vines, grass-like plants, scattered trees and herbs. The varied habitats of phoehoe (smooth, ropy lava), and a flats, drifted sand, anchialine pond shores, protected beaches, and sea spray battered bluffs each support different native plant communities. In the reconnaissance survey, fourteen species of coastal strand plants (six trees, seven ground cover or shrubforms and the invasive aquatic water hyacinth. Native plants such as naupaka kahakai, ilima ku kahakai, and phuehue. were found in the area.
==Pools, Ponds, and Estuaries== The second largest spring complex on Hawaii Island is located at Punaluu and Ninole Cove. Stretching from Punalu`u to Nnole Springs through Kwa to Honuapo, is a series of wetlands fed by basal springs and intermittent streams that support a broad range of native fauna. These spring and pool complexes contain individuals, particularly juveniles or recruits, of several marine invertebrates and fishes, suggesting it may be a significant refuge or nursery area for nearshore marine fauna on the southern coast of Hawaii Island.
==Punalu`us Anchialine Pools== [[Anchialine pool]]s of various types occur near and around Punalu`u and Ninole Cove. These pools are rare and localized brackish waters along coastal lava flows that exhibit tidal fluctuations without a surface connection to the sea. They include open pools near the shore as well as undisturbed pools in collapsed lava tubes, cracks, and caves. Endemic and native shrimp species live in pools and travel between and through them through underground cracks. The orange-black damselfly breeds in the [[anchialine pool]]s while native insects perch on the nearby vegetation. Throughout the state, anchialine species are severely threatened by alien insects, by habitat loss due to coastal development, and by other human impacts.
Anchialine ponds are one of Hawaiis most threatened ecosystems. [[Anchialine pool]]s are landlocked brackish ponds located close to the shoreline connected to the ocean via subterranean tunnels. Characterized by tidal fluctuations, these rare and fragile ponds are home to unusual plants and animals.

Formed by volcanic activity, these pools are home to a unique assemblage of invertebrate and algal species, some of which are known to exist only in this habitat. In the last 20 years, alien fish species have been introduced and/or invaded a majority of the pools. These alien species have gradually destroyed the ecological balance in many of the pools by eliminating many of unique endemic species.

The pristine, spring fed waters of Punalu`u mixing with the salt water of the ocean provide ideal habitat for a variety of fish that live in these naturally created koa. There are several koa just offshore from Punalu`u still used by local fishermen. Each koa is identified by the species of fish that live there, including yellow fin tuna and mackerel. In the old days, Hawaiian families would feed the fish in the koa cooked taro and pumpkin and the fish in return, would provide a constant source of protien.

After 1850, when the Hawaiian government began selling land, the Privy Council refused to permit any fishponds to be sold. They were all reserved for the government, to be used by the people.
==Development==
There is an ongoing discussion of a proposed redevelopment of the infrastructure currently serving Punalu{{okina}}u. Sea Mountain V hopes to bring new jobs, new job training, and a partnership with [[Jean-Michel Cousteau]]'s Ocean Futures Society [http://www.oceanfutures.org] for marine and land protection programs.
Sea Mountain V has stated that the complex will be environmentally friendly, and that the proposed Sea Mountain complex will renew the current infrastructure at Punalu{{okina}}u, enhancing the area between Pahala and N{{okina}}lehu. Sea Mountain V has also offered to donate land to create a 17-acre park, as well as create a shoreline preservation area that will restrict the designated shoreline area so no buildings will be allowed except those shown on the shoreline plan.

However, others in the area oppose this project becuase they believe that it will significantly damage the environment.
Through collaborative conversations with the community in 2005 and 2006, the revised development is scaled significantly back from the original proposal. Todays development calls for 1,400 total hotel and residential units spread over a 434-acre area. All buildings will be pushed far back from the shoreline, between 300 and 600 feet off the beach. In addition, the developer is working with community to create a Cultural Center for the region of Ka{{okina}}.

The volcanic activity is now in [[Hawaii Volcanoes National Park|Hawai{{okina}}i Volcanoes National Park]].
Punalu{{okina}}u is frequented by endangered [[Hawksbill Turtle]]s and [[Green Sea Turtle]]s, which can often be seen basking on the black sand. Visitors must remain 15 feet from the turtles at all times. The swimming area is very rocky, and it can be dangerous to swim.

Camping is permitted at Punalu{{okina}}u Black Sand Beach Park.

With the advent of Missionaries arriving in the district as early as 1833, Christianity left its distinct architectural hallmark on the landscape of Ka`u. There are three pre-contact heiau within the immediate vicinity of Punalu`u. The walled heiau was introduced to Hawaii about A.D. 1100 and Punalu`u is one of the last places in Hawaii where one can enjoy an unaltered view from one heiau to the next.

Thought to be a fishing shrine the heiau was built on a prominent bluff overlooking the ocean to the south, what were once the Ninole fishponds to the west and Koloa Bay to the east - home of the legendary na `ili`ili hanau (birthing stones) said to have supernatural ability to propagate. These smooth, water-polished stones were highly desired and were used for paving heiau, for arming slingshots and as game pieces for the Hawaiian game konane. The name Ka`ie`ie is thought to refer to a type of fishing trap or weir made of the fibrous `ie`ie vine. Considered, to be in good condition by early surveyors, several walls and a raised stone platform are all that remain of Ka`ie`ie today. Recent scholarship has interpreted the site as multi-functional. It likely served as a place of offerings and tributes, an observation point for monitoring the fishponds as well as a communications relay and dissemination location.
The heiau complex of Lanipau has not faired as well. Heavily impacted by the construction of the Sea Mountain Resort golf course. Once the largest of the three, today what remains of Lanipau is in essence an island swallowed up by a sea of putting and driving greens.
The heiau complex that sits overlooking the ocean and Punalu`u Beach is referred to by many names including, Halelau, Kane`ele`ele; Mailekini or Punalu`u Nui. This hieau, likely extended to the edge of the cliff at Punalu`u Bay. Its westernmost boundary was destroyed to make way for the construction of a wharf/warehouse complex for the sugar company in 1906. Identified as a heiau luakini (human sacrafice temple), a large table-like stone rests outside the southernmost wall and is known locally as Pohaku Mohai (sacrificial stone). Early site surveys noted possible kauhale (houses) adjacent to the heiau that were likely the residences of na kahuna (religious specialists).

Recent scholarship has interpreted the site as multi-functional. It likely served as a place of offerings and tributes, an observation point for monitoring the fishponds as well as a communications relay and dissemination location.
The heiau complex of Lanipau has not faired as well. Heavily impacted by the construction of the Sea Mountain Resort golf course. Once the largest of the three, today what remains of Lanipau is in essence an island swallowed up by a sea of putting and driving greens.

In the [[Hawaiian Islands]], more than 90% of honu ea nests are found on the Big Island. Researchers estimate there are fewer than 80 nesting honu ea in the Hawaiian islands, of which 67 nest on the island of Hawaii. Sea Mountain V in consultancy with [http://www.group70int.com Group 70 International, Inc.] hope to bring new jobs, new job training, and a partnership with [[Jean-Michel Cousteau]]'s Ocean Futures Society [http://www.oceanfutures.org] for marine and land protection programs.
Sea Mountain V and [http://www.group70int.com Group 70 International, Inc.] have stated that the complex will be environmentally friendly, and that the proposed Sea Mountain complex will renew the current infrastructure at Punalu{{okina}}u, enhancing the area between Pahala and N{{okina}}lehu. Through collaborative conversations with a single community group - O Ka'u Kakou - in 2005 and 2006, the revised development is scaled significantly back from the original proposal. Todays development calls for 1,400 total hotel and residential units spread over a 434-acre area. All buildings will be pushed far back from the shoreline, between 300 and 600 feet off the beach. In addition, the developer is working with community to create a Cultural Center for the region of Ka{{okina}}.
Sea Mountain V, owners and leaseholders of the County of Hawaii's beach park at Punalu{{okina}}u, has stated it would donate land to create a 17-acre park, as well as create a shoreline preservation area that will restrict the designated shoreline area so no buildings will be allowed except those shown on the shoreline plan.
The County of Hawaii, and it's Finance Committee, has recently held public hearings to gauge public sentiment regarding the feasibility of acquiring 150-acres of land in the area of the current beach park through Hawaii County's 2% Land Acquisition Fund, and with matching Federal Funding earmarked toward the land acquisition through legislation introduced by US Congresswoman [[Mazie Hirono]].
Most people in the Punalu{{okina}}u area support the land acquisition and preservation of the Punalu{{okina}}u's significantly cultural areas and pristine beach area, while others support the Sea Mountain V/Group 70 International project, seeking to bring a new economic driver to the area, which began to decline with the closing of the sugar plantations in the 1980s and 90s.

'''Punalu{{okina}}u Black Sand Beach''' is a beach near [[N'lehu, Hawai'i|N{{okina}}lehu]] on the [[Hawaii (island)|Big Island]] of the [[U.S. state]] of [[Hawaii|Hawai{{okina}}i]] that has [[black sand]] created by volcanic activity. This occurs when the lava flows into the ocean and explodes when it cools as it hits the ocean. The volcanic activity is now in [[Hawaii Volcanoes National Park|Hawai{{okina}}i Volcanoes National Park]].
Punalu{{okina}}u is frequented by endangered [[Hawksbill Turtle]]s and [[Green Sea Turtle]]s, which can often be seen basking on the black sand. Visitors must remain 15 feet from the turtles at all times. The swimming area is very rocky, and it can be dangerous to swim.
Taking black sand is prohibited but, as with volcanic rocks, local tradition says that if any of the black sand from Punalu{{okina}}u Beach is taken away from Hawai{{okina}}i that the person that took it will be cursed until it is returned. Camping is permitted at Punalu{{okina}}u Black Sand Beach Park.
The beach has a large amount of underground fresh water that flows in it. This fresh water is very cold and looks almost like gasoline mixing with the water. Legend has it that in the time of drought, the early Hawaiians living in the area would dive underwater with a jug to get their fresh water.
==Wahi Pana O Punalu'u: The Sacred Sites of Punalu`u==
Punalu`u and adjacent areas provide evidence of the shifts in use of sacred space over time. Monumental architecture in the form of large heiau complexes (ritual centers) speak to the power of na ali`i (the Chiefs) and the social stratification of Ka`us ancient feudal society. With the advent of Missionaries arriving in the district as early as 1833, Christianity left its distinct architectural hallmark on the landscape of Ka`u. Sitting high on the ridge above Punalu`u is the Opukahaia Memorial Chapel and graveyard built on the birthplace of Henry Opukahaia (1792-1818) who inspired the missionary movement that forever changed Hawai`i.
There are three pre-contact heiau within the immediate vicinity of Punalu`u. The walled heiau was introduced to Hawaii about A.D. 1100 and Punalu`u is one of the last places in Hawaii where one can enjoy an unaltered view from one heiau to the next.
To the south lies Ka`ie`ie Heiau. Thought to be a fishing shrine the heiau was built on a prominent bluff overlooking the ocean to the south, what were once the Ninole fishponds to the west and Koloa Bay to the east - home of the legendary na `ili`ili hanau (birthing stones) said to have supernatural ability to propagate. These smooth, water-polished stones were highly desired and were used for paving heiau, for arming slingshots and as game pieces for the Hawaiian game konane. The name Ka`ie`ie is thought to refer to a type of fishing trap or weir made of the fibrous `ie`ie vine. Considered, to be in good condition by early surveyors, several walls and a raised stone platform are all that remain of Ka`ie`ie today. Recent scholarship has interpreted the site as multi-functional. It likely served as a place of offerings and tributes, an observation point for monitoring the fishponds as well as a communications relay and dissemination location.
The heiau complex of Lanipau has not faired as well. Heavily impacted by the construction of the Sea Mountain Resort golf course. Once the largest of the three, today what remains of Lanipau is in essence an island swallowed up by a sea of putting and driving greens.
The heiau complex that sits overlooking the ocean and Punalu`u Beach is referred to by many names including, Halelau, Kane`ele`ele; Mailekini or Punalu`u Nui. This hieau, likely extended to the edge of the cliff at Punalu`u Bay. Its westernmost boundary was destroyed to make way for the construction of a wharf/warehouse complex for the sugar company in 1906. Identified as a heiau luakini (human sacrafice temple), a large table-like stone rests outside the southernmost wall and is known locally as Pohaku Mohai (sacrificial stone). Early site surveys noted possible kauhale (houses) adjacent to the heiau that were likely the residences of na kahuna (religious specialists).
Another important cultural feature is ala kahakai (trail by the sea) that served as an important link between ritual centers and coastal communities. A path with divine origins, the ala kahakai was thought to be the original route taken by the God Lono from North Kohala to the southernmost tip of the island and then windward along the Ka`u coast to Puna. This trail once paved with the `ili`ili hanau, (birthing stones) was designated as a National Historic Trail by President Clinton in 2000 and remnants can be found at both Punalu`u Nui and Ka`ie`ie heiau.
Kii pohaku (petroglyphs) can be found near the County Park Pavilions within a protected area surrounded by a rock wall just past the parking area. It is easy to miss these unmarked ancient carvings.
Please kokua: While visiting Hawaiian wahi pana or sacred spaces please keep in mind that many wahi pana are still being used today by native Hawaiians. Treat them with the reverence due any sacred site modern or ancient.
==Endangered Species== Rare and endangered native animals known at Punalu`u and Ninole are the honu ea ([[Hawksbill Turtle]] )and honu ([[Green Sea Turtle]]), [[Hawaiian monk seal]], native bees, orange-black damselfly, and other [[anchialine pool]] fauna. Native birds are seen near the shore and cliffs or fly over the area on their way to the sea from upland nesting colonies, including the endangered [[Hawaiian hawk]] ('io) that nests in the trees at Punalu`u. [[Spinner dolphin]]s and [[humpback whale]]s can also be sighted offshore from Punaluu. Residents say such sightings are common. A rare sighting of a [[Hawaiian monk seal]] was reported at Punalu`u in Sept. of 2006 near the boat ramp, and several known nesting sites of the endangered [[Hawksbill Turtle]] (honu ea) are located along the Punalu`u and Ninole area. Such occurrences indicate a healthy environment with adequate resources to support large marine animals.
The [[Green Sea Turtle]], or honu ea (Eretmochelys imbricate) is a federally listed endangered species and is the rarest sea turtle in the Pacific Ocean. In the [[Hawaiian Islands]], more than 90% of honu ea nests are found on the Big Island. Researchers estimate there are fewer than 80 nesting honu ea in the Hawaiian islands, of which 67 nest on the island of Hawaii. More than half of the known nesting population statewide, 40 individuals nest along the southeast boundary of Hawaii Volcanoes National park to Waikapuna. The shoreline should be considered a critical and ecologically significant nesting coastline for honu ea.
The threatened [[green sea turtle]] or honu (Chelonia mydas) feeds on marine plants in shallow waters along the coastline. Punaluu is an especially well known site for honu. Red seaweed, a favorite food of the honu flourishes on the coral-encrusted rocks in the shallow waters of the bay and the turtles are found basking on the black sand beach despite the presence of beachgoers. Researchers with the National Marine Fisheries have been studying the honu at Punaluu since 1982 along with groups of Hawaii students.
The endangered [[Hawaiian Hoary Bat]], opeapea, (Lasirus cinereus semotus), is known to fly over and reside at Punalu`u. The [[Hawaiian Hoary Bat]]s habitat stretches from sea level to over 13,000 feet It usually weighs about 5 to 8 ounces, is nocturnal and feeds on insects. Relatively little research has been done on this endemic Hawaiian bat and data regarding its habitat and population status is very limited.
One of the largest populations of the rare orange-black damselfly (Megalagrion xanthomelas) can be found at Ninole. It is a candidate endangered species and thrives in the aquatic habitat of the extensive spring complex that stretches from Nnole Springs to the estuary at Honuapo. Systematic surveys have observed damselfly populations at Kwa, Hlea, Nnole, and Honuapo. The highest densities occur at the back of estuarine marshes, at the mouth of Hlea and Nnole Streams, and at Kwa Springs.
==Vegetation== The native plant communities generally appear as a narrow strand of vegetation, mostly a flattened growth of various shrubs, vines, grass-like plants, scattered trees and herbs. The varied habitats of phoehoe (smooth, ropy lava), and a flats, drifted sand, anchialine pond shores, protected beaches, and sea spray battered bluffs each support different native plant communities. In the reconnaissance survey, fourteen species of coastal strand plants (six trees, seven ground cover or shrubforms and the invasive aquatic water hyacinth. Native plants such as naupaka kahakai, ilima ku kahakai, and phuehue. were found in the area.
==Pools, Ponds, and Estuaries== The second largest spring complex on Hawaii Island is located at Punaluu and Ninole Cove. Stretching from Punalu`u to Nnole Springs through Kwa to Honuapo, is a series of wetlands fed by basal springs and intermittent streams that support a broad range of native fauna. These spring and pool complexes contain individuals, particularly juveniles or recruits, of several marine invertebrates and fishes, suggesting it may be a significant refuge or nursery area for nearshore marine fauna on the southern coast of Hawaii Island.
==Punalu`us Anchialine Pools== [[Anchialine pool]]s of various types occur near and around Punalu`u and Ninole Cove. These pools are rare and localized brackish waters along coastal lava flows that exhibit tidal fluctuations without a surface connection to the sea. They include open pools near the shore as well as undisturbed pools in collapsed lava tubes, cracks, and caves. Endemic and native shrimp species live in pools and travel between and through them through underground cracks. The orange-black damselfly breeds in the [[anchialine pool]]s while native insects perch on the nearby vegetation. Throughout the state, anchialine species are severely threatened by alien insects, by habitat loss due to coastal development, and by other human impacts.
Anchialine ponds are one of Hawaiis most threatened ecosystems. [[Anchialine pool]]s are landlocked brackish ponds located close to the shoreline connected to the ocean via subterranean tunnels. Characterized by tidal fluctuations, these rare and fragile ponds are home to unusual plants and animals.
In the U.S., this habitat exists only in the Hawaiian Islands and, of the approximately 700 known [[anchialine pool]]s, the majority are located on the island of Hawaii. Formed by volcanic activity, these pools are home to a unique assemblage of invertebrate and algal species, some of which are known to exist only in this habitat. In the last 20 years, alien fish species have been introduced and/or invaded a majority of the pools. These alien species have gradually destroyed the ecological balance in many of the pools by eliminating many of unique endemic species.
==Koa Fish Houses== Punalu`u has long been know for its koa (fish houses) where specific species of fish live in specific areas offshore. The pristine, spring fed waters of Punalu`u mixing with the salt water of the ocean provide ideal habitat for a variety of fish that live in these naturally created koa. There are several koa just offshore from Punalu`u still used by local fishermen. Each koa is identified by the species of fish that live there, including [[yellow fin tuna]] (ahi) and [[mackerel]] (ono, or [[wahoo]]). In the old days, Hawaiian families would feed the fish in the koa cooked [[taro]] and pumpkin and the fish in return, would provide a constant source of protein.
==Ownership of Ponds== The Civil Code of the Hawaiian kingdom did not allow the sale of fishponds or wetlands as these were resources of the common people. After 1850, when the Hawaiian government began selling land, the Privy Council refused to permit any fishponds to be sold. They were all reserved for the government, to be used by the people.

[[Image:Punaluu turtle.jpg|right|thumb|200px|A [[Green Sea Turtle]] resting on Punalu{{okina}}u Black Sand Beach <small>(Photo: [http://www.andhawaii.com/big-island/punaluu_beach.html Lisa Weber])</small>]]
'''Punalu{{okina}}u Black Sand Beach''' is a beach near [[N'lehu, Hawai'i|N{{okina}}lehu]] on the [[Hawaii (island)|Big Island]] of the [[U.S. state]] of [[Hawaii|Hawai{{okina}}i]]. The beach has [[black sand]] created by lava flowing into the ocean which explodes as it reaches the ocean and cools. This volcanic activity is in the [[Hawaii Volcanoes National Park|Hawai{{okina}}i Volcanoes National Park]].
Punalu{{okina}}u is frequented by endangered [[Hawksbill Turtle]]s and [[Green Sea Turtle]]s, which can often be seen basking on the black sand. Visitors must remain 15 feet from the turtles at all times. The swimming area is very rocky, and it can be dangerous to swim. The beach also has a large amount of underground fresh water that flows in it. This fresh water is very cold and looks almost like gasoline mixing with the water. Legend has it that in the time of drought, the early Hawaiians living in the area would dive underwater with a jug to get their fresh water.{{fact|date=June 2007}}
Taking black sand and volcanic rocks from the area is prohibited. Local tradition says that if any of the black sand from Punalu{{okina}}u Beach is taken away from Hawai{{okina}}i, then the person that took it will be cursed until it is returned.{{fact|date=June 2007}} Camping is permitted at the Punalu{{okina}}u Black Sand Beach Park.
==Wahi Pana O Punalu'u== [[Image:Punaluu_Black_Sand_Beach.JPG|right|thumb|200px|Punalu{{okina}}u Black Sand Beach <small>(Photo: [http://kenya.allmond.us Kenya Allmond])</small>]]
Punalu`u and adjacent areas provide evidence of the shifts in use of sacred space over time. Monumental architecture in the form of large heiau complexes (ritual centers) speak to the power of na ali`i (the Chiefs) and the social stratification of Ka`us ancient feudal society. With the advent of Missionaries arriving in the district as early as 1833, Christianity left its distinct architectural hallmark on the landscape of Ka`u. Sitting high on the ridge above Punalu`u is the Opukahaia Memorial Chapel and graveyard built on the birthplace of Henry Opukahaia (1792-1818) who inspired the missionary movement that forever changed Hawai`i.
There are three pre-contact heiau within the immediate vicinity of Punalu`u. The walled heiau was introduced to Hawaii about A.D. 1100 and Punalu`u is one of the last places in Hawaii where one can enjoy an unaltered view from one heiau to the next.
To the south lies Ka`ie`ie Heiau. Thought to be a fishing shrine the heiau was built on a prominent bluff overlooking the ocean to the south, what were once the Ninole fishponds to the west and Koloa Bay to the east - home of the legendary na `ili`ili hanau (birthing stones) said to have supernatural ability to propagate. These smooth, water-polished stones were highly desired and were used for paving heiau, for arming slingshots and as game pieces for the Hawaiian game konane. The name Ka`ie`ie is thought to refer to a type of fishing trap or weir made of the fibrous `ie`ie vine. Considered, to be in good condition by early surveyors, several walls and a raised stone platform are all that remain of Ka`ie`ie today. Recent scholarship has interpreted the site as multi-functional. It likely served as a place of offerings and tributes, an observation point for monitoring the fishponds as well as a communications relay and dissemination location.
The heiau complex of Lanipau has not faired as well. Heavily impacted by the construction of the Sea Mountain Resort golf course. Once the largest of the three, today what remains of Lanipau is in essence an island swallowed up by a sea of putting and driving greens.
The heiau complex that sits overlooking the ocean and Punalu`u Beach is referred to by many names including, Halelau, Kane`ele`ele; Mailekini or Punalu`u Nui. This hieau, likely extended to the edge of the cliff at Punalu`u Bay. Its westernmost boundary was destroyed to make way for the construction of a wharf/warehouse complex for the sugar company in 1906. Identified as a heiau luakini (human sacrafice temple), a large table-like stone rests outside the southernmost wall and is known locally as Pohaku Mohai (sacrificial stone). Early site surveys noted possible kauhale (houses) adjacent to the heiau that were likely the residences of na kahuna (religious specialists).
Another important cultural feature is ala kahakai (trail by the sea) that served as an important link between ritual centers and coastal communities. A path with divine origins, the ala kahakai was thought to be the original route taken by the God Lono from North Kohala to the southernmost tip of the island and then windward along the Ka`u coast to Puna. This trail once paved with the `ili`ili hanau, (birthing stones) was designated as a National Historic Trail by President Clinton in 2000 and remnants can be found at both Punalu`u Nui and Ka`ie`ie heiau.
Kii pohaku (petroglyphs) can be found near the County Park Pavilions within a protected area surrounded by a rock wall just past the parking area. It is easy to miss these unmarked ancient carvings.
Please kokua: While visiting Hawaiian wahi pana or sacred spaces please keep in mind that many wahi pana are still being used today by native Hawaiians. Treat them with the reverence due any sacred site modern or ancient.
==Endangered species== Rare and endangered native animals known at Punalu`u and Ninole are the honu ea ([[Hawksbill Turtle]] )and honu ([[Green Sea Turtle]]), [[Hawaiian monk seal]], native bees, orange-black damselfly, and other [[anchialine pool]] fauna. Native birds are seen near the shore and cliffs or fly over the area on their way to the sea from upland nesting colonies, including the endangered [[Hawaiian hawk]] ('io) that nests in the trees at Punalu`u. [[Spinner dolphin]]s and [[humpback whale]]s can also be sighted offshore from Punaluu. Residents say such sightings are common. A rare sighting of a [[Hawaiian monk seal]] was reported at Punalu`u in Sept. of 2006 near the boat ramp, and several known nesting sites of the endangered [[Hawksbill Turtle]] (honu ea) are located along the Punalu`u and Ninole area. Such occurrences indicate a healthy environment with adequate resources to support large marine animals.
The [[Green Sea Turtle]], or honu ea (Eretmochelys imbricate) is a federally listed endangered species and is the rarest sea turtle in the Pacific Ocean. In the [[Hawaiian Islands]], more than 90% of honu ea nests are found on the Big Island. Researchers estimate there are fewer than 80 nesting honu ea in the Hawaiian islands, of which 67 nest on the island of Hawaii. More than half of the known nesting population statewide, 40 individuals nest along the southeast boundary of Hawaii Volcanoes National park to Waikapuna. The shoreline should be considered a critical and ecologically significant nesting coastline for honu ea.
The threatened [[green sea turtle]] or honu (Chelonia mydas) feeds on marine plants in shallow waters along the coastline. Punaluu is an especially well known site for honu. Red seaweed, a favorite food of the honu flourishes on the coral-encrusted rocks in the shallow waters of the bay and the turtles are found basking on the black sand beach despite the presence of beachgoers. Researchers with the National Marine Fisheries have been studying the honu at Punaluu since 1982 along with groups of Hawaii students.
The endangered [[Hawaiian Hoary Bat]], opeapea, (Lasirus cinereus semotus), is known to fly over and reside at Punalu`u. The [[Hawaiian Hoary Bat]]s habitat stretches from sea level to over 13,000 feet It usually weighs about 5 to 8 ounces, is nocturnal and feeds on insects. Relatively little research has been done on this endemic Hawaiian bat and data regarding its habitat and population status is very limited.
One of the largest populations of the rare orange-black damselfly (Megalagrion xanthomelas) can be found at Ninole. It is a candidate endangered species and thrives in the aquatic habitat of the extensive spring complex that stretches from Nnole Springs to the estuary at Honuapo. Systematic surveys have observed damselfly populations at Kwa, Hlea, Nnole, and Honuapo. The highest densities occur at the back of estuarine marshes, at the mouth of Hlea and Nnole Streams, and at Kwa Springs.
==Vegetation== The native plant communities generally appear as a narrow strand of vegetation, mostly a flattened growth of various shrubs, vines, grass-like plants, scattered trees and herbs. The varied habitats of phoehoe (smooth, ropy lava), and a flats, drifted sand, anchialine pond shores, protected beaches, and sea spray battered bluffs each support different native plant communities. In the reconnaissance survey, fourteen species of coastal strand plants (six trees, seven ground cover or shrubforms and the invasive aquatic water hyacinth. Native plants such as naupaka kahakai, ilima ku kahakai, and phuehue. were found in the area.
==Wetlands== The second largest spring complex on Hawaii Island is located at Punaluu and Ninole Cove. Stretching from Punalu`u to Nnole Springs through Kwa to Honuapo, is a series of wetlands fed by basal springs and intermittent streams that support a broad range of native fauna. These spring and pool complexes contain individuals, particularly juveniles or recruits, of several marine invertebrates and fishes, suggesting it may be a significant refuge or nursery area for nearshore marine fauna on the southern coast of Hawaii Island.
==Anchialine pools== [[Anchialine pool]]s of various types occur near and around Punalu`u and Ninole Cove. These pools are rare and localized brackish waters along coastal lava flows that exhibit tidal fluctuations without a surface connection to the sea. They include open pools near the shore as well as undisturbed pools in collapsed lava tubes, cracks, and caves. Endemic and native shrimp species live in pools and travel between and through them through underground cracks. The orange-black damselfly breeds in the [[anchialine pool]]s while native insects perch on the nearby vegetation. Throughout the state, anchialine species are severely threatened by alien insects, by habitat loss due to coastal development, and by other human impacts.
Anchialine ponds are one of Hawaiis most threatened ecosystems. [[Anchialine pool]]s are landlocked brackish ponds located close to the shoreline connected to the ocean via subterranean tunnels. Characterized by tidal fluctuations, these rare and fragile ponds are home to unusual plants and animals.
In the U.S., this habitat exists only in the Hawaiian Islands and, of the approximately 700 known [[anchialine pool]]s, the majority are located on the island of Hawaii. Formed by volcanic activity, these pools are home to a unique assemblage of invertebrate and algal species, some of which are known to exist only in this habitat. In the last 20 years, alien fish species have been introduced and/or invaded a majority of the pools. These alien species have gradually destroyed the ecological balance in many of the pools by eliminating many of unique endemic species.
==Koa== Punalu`u has long been know for its koa (fish houses) where specific species of fish live in specific areas offshore. The pristine, spring fed waters of Punalu`u mixing with the salt water of the ocean provide ideal habitat for a variety of fish that live in these naturally created koa. There are several koa just offshore from Punalu`u still used by local fishermen. Each koa is identified by the species of fish that live there, including [[yellow fin tuna]] (ahi) and [[mackerel]] (ono, or [[wahoo]]). In the old days, Hawaiian families would feed the fish in the koa cooked [[taro]] and pumpkin and the fish in return, would provide a constant source of protein.
==Ownership== The Civil Code of the Hawaiian kingdom did not allow the sale of fishponds or wetlands as these were resources of the common people. After 1850, when the Hawaiian government began selling land, the Privy Council refused to permit any fishponds to be sold. They were all reserved for the government, to be used by the people.
==Development== {{POV-check-section}} There is an ongoing discussion of a proposed redevelopment of the infrastructure currently serving Punalu{{okina}}u. Sea Mountain V in consultancy with Group 70 International, Inc.<ref>http://www.group70int.com </ref> hope to bring new jobs, new job training, and a partnership with [[Jean-Michel Cousteau]]'s Ocean Futures Society [http://www.oceanfutures.org] for marine and land protection programs.
Sea Mountain V and Group 70 International, Inc.<ref>http://www.group70int.com</ref> have stated that the complex will be environmentally friendly, and that the proposed Sea Mountain complex will renew the current infrastructure at Punalu{{okina}}u, enhancing the area between Pahala and N{{okina}}lehu. Through collaborative conversations with a single community group - O Ka'u Kakou - in 2005 and 2006, the revised development is scaled significantly back from the original proposal. Todays development calls for 1,400 total hotel and residential units spread over a 434-acre area. All buildings will be pushed far back from the shoreline, between 300 and 600 feet off the beach. In addition, the developer is working with community to create a Cultural Center for the region of Ka{{okina}}.
Sea Mountain V, owners and leaseholders of the County of Hawaii's beach park at Punalu{{okina}}u, has stated it would donate land to create a 17-acre park, as well as create a shoreline preservation area that will restrict the designated shoreline area so no buildings will be allowed except those shown on the shoreline plan.
The County of Hawaii, and it's Finance Committee, has recently held public hearings to gauge public sentiment regarding the feasibility of acquiring 150-acres of land in the area of the current beach park through Hawaii County's 2% Land Acquisition Fund, and with matching Federal Funding earmarked toward the land acquisition through legislation introduced by US Congresswoman [[Mazie Hirono]].
The community group Ka'u Preservation<ref>http://www.kaupreservation.org </ref> and its membership and others support the land acquisition proposal and preservation of Punalu{{okina}}u's significantly cultural areas and pristine beach area, while the community group O Ka'u Kakou and its membership and others support the Sea Mountain V/Group 70 International project, seeking to bring a new economic driver to the area, which began to decline with the closing of the sugar plantations in the 1980s and 90s.
