Native birds are seen near the shore and cliffs or fly over the area on their way to the sea from upland nesting colonies, including the endangered [[Hawaiian hawk]] ({{okina}}io) that nests in the trees at Punalu{{okina}}u. [[Spinner Dolphin]]s and [[Humpback Whale]]s can also be sighted offshore from Punalu{{okina}}u. Residents say such sightings are common. A rare sighting of a Hawaiian Monk Seal was reported at Punalu{{okina}}u in September 2006 near the boat ramp, and several known nesting sites of the endangered honu ea are located along the Punalu{{okina}}u and Ninole area. Such occurrences indicate a healthy environment with adequate resources to support large marine animals.
The Hawksbill Turtle, or ''honu ea'' (Eretmochelys imbricata) is a federally listed endangered species and is the rarest sea turtle in the Pacific Ocean. In the [[Hawaiian Islands]], more than 90% of honu ea nests are found on the Big Island. Researchers estimate there are fewer than 80 nesting honu ea in the Hawaiian islands, of which 67 nest on the island of Hawai{{okina}}i. More than half of the known nesting population statewide, 40 individuals nest along the southeast boundary of Hawai{{okina}}i Volcanoes National park to Waikapuna. The threatened [[Green turtle]] or honu (Chelonia mydas) feeds on marine plants in shallow waters along the coastline. Punalu{{okina}}u is an especially well known site for honu. Red seaweed, a favorite food of the honu flourishes on the coral-encrusted rocks in the shallow waters of the bay and the turtles are found basking on the black sand beach despite the presence of beachgoers. Researchers with the National Marine Fisheries have been studying the honu here since 1982 along with groups of students. Visitors must remain {{convert|15|ft|m|abbr=on}} from the turtles at all times.
The endangered [[Hawaiian Hoary bat]], {{okina}}ope{{okina}}ape{{okina}}a, (''Lasirus cinereus semotus''), is known to fly over and reside at Punalu{{okina}}u. Their habitat stretches from sea level to over 13,000 feet It usually weighs about 5 to 8 ounces, is nocturnal and feeds on insects. Relatively little research has been done on this endemic Hawaiian bat and data regarding its habitat and population status is very limited.
One of the largest populations of the rare orange-black damselfly (''[[Megalagrion xanthomelas]]'') can be found at Ninole. [[File:Green turtle Chelonia mydas is basking on Punaluu Beach Big Island of Hawaii.jpg|right|thumb|200px|A [[Green turtle]] basking on the beach]]

The beach has [[black sand]] made of [[basalt]] and created by lava flowing into the ocean which explodes as it reaches the ocean and cools. This volcanic activity is in the [[Hawaii Volcanoes National Park|Hawai{{okina}}i Volcanoes National Park]]. Punalu{{okina}}u is frequented by endangered [[Hawksbill turtle|Hawksbill]] and [[Green turtle]]s, which can often be seen basking on the black sand.
==The beach== The swimming area is very rocky, and it can be dangerous to swim. The beach also has a large amount of underground fresh water that flows in it. This fresh water is very cold and looks almost like gasoline mixing with the water. Legend has it that in the time of drought, the [[ancient Hawaii]]ans living in the area would dive underwater with a jug to get their fresh water. In the [[Hawaiian language]] ''puna lu{{okina}}u'' means "spring [water] diver for".<ref>{{Hawaiian Dictionaries |Punalu'u |dic=cl |accessdate= November 8, 2010 }}</ref> The beach is located at coordinates {{coord|19.136|N|155.504|W| display=inline,title| type:landmark_region:US-HI}}. Access is from the [[Hawaii Belt Road]]: take Ninole loop road or the entrance to Sea Mountain Resort. Camping is permitted at the Punalu{{okina}}u Black Sand Beach Park.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.co.hawaii.hi.us/planning/spa/kau/map2.html |title=Ka{{okina}} map |work=Shoreline access |publisher=on official Hawai{{okina}}i County web site |accessdate=2009-10-24}}</ref>

Punalu{{okina}}u and adjacent areas provide evidence of the shifts in use of sacred space over time. Monumental architecture in the form of large [[heiau]] complexes (ritual centers) speak to the power of the [[Ali'i|ali{{okina}}i]] (ruling class) and the social stratification of the ancient [[Kau, Hawaii|Ka{{okina}} district]]. With the advent of [[List of Missionaries to Hawaii|missionaries]] arriving in the district as early as 1833, [[Christianity]] left its distinct architectural hallmark on the landscape of Ka{{okina}}. Sitting on the ridge above Punalu{{okina}}u is the Hkloa Church, a Memorial Chapel and graveyard built near the birthplace of [[Henry Opukahaia|Henry {{okina}}pkaha{{okina}}ia]] (17921818) who inspired the missionary movement that forever changed Hawaii.<ref>{{Hawaiian Dictionaries |Hkloa |q=Hokuloa |dic=cl |accessdate= November 8, 2010 }}</ref>
There are three pre-contact heiau within the immediate vicinity of Punalu{{okina}}u. The walled heiau was introduced to Hawaii about 1100 and Punalu{{okina}}uu is one of the last places in Hawaii where one can enjoy an unaltered view from one heiau to the next.
To the south lies Ka{{okina}}ie{{okina}}ie Heiau. Thought to be a fishing shrine the heiau was built on a prominent bluff overlooking the ocean to the south, what were once the Ninole [[Ancient Hawaiian aquaculture|fishponds]] to the west and Koloa Bay to the easthome of the legendary na {{okina}}ili{{okina}}ili hanau (birthing stones) said to have supernatural ability to propagate. These smooth, water-polished stones were highly desired and were used for paving heiau, for arming slingshots and as game pieces for the Hawaiian game konane. The name Ka{{okina}}ie{{okina}}ie is thought to refer to a type of fishing trap or weir made of the fibrous [[Freycinetia arborea|{{okina}}ie{{okina}}ie]] vine. Considered to be in good condition by early surveyors, several walls and a raised stone platform are all that remain of Ka{{okina}}ie{{okina}}ie today. Recent scholarship has interpreted the site as multi-functional. It likely served as a place of offerings and tributes, an observation point for monitoring the fishponds as well as a communications relay and dissemination location.
The heiau complex of Lanipau was heavily impacted by the construction of the Sea Mountain Resort golf course. Once the largest of the three, today what remains of Lanipau is in essence an island swallowed up by a sea of putting and driving greens.
The heiau complex that sits overlooking the ocean and Punalu{{okina}}u Beach is referred to by many names including Halelau, Kane{{okina}}ele{{okina}}ele; Mailekini or Punalu{{okina}}u Nui. This trail once paved with the na {{okina}}ili{{okina}}ili hanau was designated as a [[National Historic Trail]] in 2000 and remnants can be found at both Punalu{{okina}}u Nui and Ka{{okina}}ie{{okina}}ie heiau.
Ki{{okina}}i pohaku ([[petroglyph]]s) can be found near the County Park Pavilions within a protected area surrounded by a rock wall just past the parking area. It is easy to miss these unmarked ancient carvings.

Native birds are seen near the shore and cliffs or fly over the area on their way to the sea from upland nesting colonies, including the endangered [[Hawaiian hawk]] ({{okina}}io) that nests in the trees at Punalu{{okina}}u. The Hawksbill Turtle (Eretmochelys imbricata), is a federally listed endangered species and is the rarest sea turtle in the Pacific Ocean. Researchers estimate there are fewer than 80 nesting Hawksbill turtles in the Hawaiian islands, of which 67 nest on the island of Hawai{{okina}}i. More than half of the known nesting population statewide, 40 individuals nest along the southeast boundary of Hawai{{okina}}i Volcanoes National park to Waikapuna.
The threatened [[Green turtle]] or honu (Chelonia mydas) feeds on marine plants in shallow waters along the coastline such as Punalu{{okina}}u. Red seaweed, a favorite food of the Green turtle flourishes on the coral-encrusted rocks in the shallow waters of the bay and the turtles are found basking on the black sand beach despite the presence of beachgoers. Researchers with the National Marine Fisheries have been studying the Green turtle since 1982 along with groups of students. Visitors must remain {{convert|15|ft|m|abbr=on}} from the turtles at all times.
The endangered [[Hawaiian Hoary bat]], {{okina}}ope{{okina}}ape{{okina}}a, (''Lasirus cinereus semotus''), is known to fly over and reside at Punalu{{okina}}u. Their habitat stretches from sea level to over 13,000 feet It usually weighs about 5 to 8 ounces, is nocturnal and feeds on insects. Relatively little research has been done on this endemic Hawaiian bat and data regarding its habitat and population status is very limited.

Systematic surveys have observed damselfly populations at Kw{{okina}}a, Hlea, Nnole, and Honu{{okina}}apo. The highest densities occur at the back of [[Estuary|estuarine]] [[Salt marsh|marsh]], at the mouth of Hlea and Nnole Streams, and at Kw{{okina}}a Springs.

The varied habitats of [[Lava#Phoehoe|phoehoe]] (smooth, ropy lava), and [[Lava#A|{{okina}}a{{okina}}]] flats, drifted sand, anchialine pond shores, protected beaches, and sea spray battered bluffs each support different native plant communities. In the reconnaissance survey, fourteen species of coastal strand plants (six trees, seven ground cover or shrub forms and the invasive aquatic [[water hyacinth]]. Native plants such as ilima (''[[Sida fallax]]''), naupaka kahakai (''[[Scaevola]] [[Scaevola sericea|sericea]]''), and phuehue (''[[Ipomoea pes-caprae|Ipomoea pes-caprae brasiliensis]]'') were found in the area.

These pools are rare and localized [[brackish water]]s along coastal lava flows that exhibit [[Tide|tidal]] fluctuations without a surface connection to the sea. They include open pools near the shore as well as undisturbed pools in collapsed [[lava tube]]s, cracks, and caves. The orange-black damselfly (''[[Megalagrion xanthomelas]]'') breeds in the anchialine pools while native insects perch on the nearby vegetation. This trail once paved with the na {{okina}}ili{{okina}}ili hanau was designated as a [[National Historic Trail]] in 2000 and remnants can be found at both Punalu{{okina}}u Nui and Ka{{okina}}ie{{okina}}ie heiau.
Ki{{okina}}i pohaku ([[petroglyph]]s) can be found near the County Park Pavilions within a protected area surrounded by a rock wall just past the parking area. It is easy to miss these unmarked ancient carvings.
==Endangered species== [[File:Punaluu turtle.jpg|right|thumb|A ''honu'' resting on Punalu{{okina}}u]] Rare and endangered native animals known at Punalu{{okina}}u and Ninole are the honu ea ([[Hawksbill turtle]]), honu ([[Green turtle]]), [[Hawaiian Monk Seal]], native bees, orange-black damselfly, and other [[anchialine pool]] fauna. Native birds are seen near the shore and cliffs or fly over the area on their way to the sea from upland nesting colonies, including the endangered [[Hawaiian hawk]] ({{okina}}io) that nests in the trees at Punalu{{okina}}u. [[Spinner Dolphin]]s and [[Humpback Whale]]s can also be sighted offshore from Punalu{{okina}}u. Residents say such sightings are common. A rare sighting of a Hawaiian Monk Seal was reported at Punalu{{okina}}u in September 2006 near the boat ramp, and several known nesting sites of the endangered Hawksbill turtles are located along the Punalu{{okina}}u and Ninole area. Such occurrences indicate a healthy environment with adequate resources to support large marine animals.

Researchers estimate there are fewer than 80 nesting Hawksbill turtles in the Hawaiian islands, of which 67 nest on the island of Hawai{{okina}}i. More than half of the known nesting population statewide, 40 individuals nest along the southeast boundary of Hawai{{okina}}i Volcanoes National park to Waikapuna.
The threatened [[Green turtle]] or honu (Chelonia mydas) feeds on marine plants in shallow waters along the coastline such as Punalu{{okina}}u. Red seaweed, a favorite food of the Green turtle flourishes on the coral-encrusted rocks in the shallow waters of the bay and the turtles are found basking on the black sand beach despite the presence of beachgoers. Researchers with the National Marine Fisheries have been studying the Green turtle since 1982 along with groups of students. Visitors must remain {{convert|15|ft|m|abbr=on}} from the turtles at all times.
The endangered [[Hawaiian Hoary bat]], {{okina}}ope{{okina}}ape{{okina}}a, (''Lasirus cinereus semotus''), is known to fly over and reside at Punalu{{okina}}u. Their habitat stretches from sea level to over 13,000 feet It usually weighs about 5 to 8 ounces, is nocturnal and feeds on insects. Relatively little research has been done on this endemic Hawaiian bat and data regarding its habitat and population status is very limited.
One of the largest populations of the rare orange-black damselfly (''[[Megalagrion xanthomelas]]'') can be found at Ninole. It is a candidate endangered species and thrives in the aquatic habitat of the extensive spring complex that stretches from Nnole Springs to the estuary at Honu{{okina}}apo. Systematic surveys have observed damselfly populations at Kw{{okina}}a, Hlea, Nnole, and Honu{{okina}}apo. The highest densities occur at the back of [[Estuary|estuarine]] [[Salt marsh|marsh]], at the mouth of Hlea and Nnole Streams, and at Kw{{okina}}a Springs.
==Vegetation== The native plant communities generally appear as a narrow strand of vegetation, mostly a flattened growth of various shrubs, vines, grass-like plants, scattered trees and herbs. The varied habitats of [[Lava#Phoehoe|phoehoe]] (smooth, ropy lava), and [[Lava#A|{{okina}}a{{okina}}]] flats, drifted sand, anchialine pond shores, protected beaches, and sea spray battered bluffs each support different native plant communities. In the reconnaissance survey, fourteen species of coastal strand plants (six trees, seven ground cover or shrub forms and the invasive aquatic [[water hyacinth]]. Native plants such as ilima (''[[Sida fallax]]''), naupaka kahakai (''[[Scaevola]] [[Scaevola sericea|sericea]]''), and phuehue (''[[Ipomoea pes-caprae|Ipomoea pes-caprae brasiliensis]]'') were found in the area.

Stretching from Punalu{{okina}}u to Nnole Springs through Kw{{okina}}a to Honu{{okina}}po, is a series of wetlands fed by basal springs and intermittent streams that support a broad range of native fauna. These spring and pool complexes contain individuals, particularly juveniles or recruits, of several marine invertebrates and fishes, suggesting it may be a significant refuge or nursery area for nearshore marine fauna on the southern coast of Hawaii Island.
==Anchialine pools== [[Anchialine pool]]s of various types occur near and around Punalu{{okina}}u and Ninole Cove. These pools are rare and localized [[brackish water]]s along coastal lava flows that exhibit [[Tide|tidal]] fluctuations without a surface connection to the sea. They include open pools near the shore as well as undisturbed pools in collapsed [[lava tube]]s, cracks, and caves. Endemic and native shrimp species live in pools and travel between and through them through underground cracks. The orange-black damselfly (''[[Megalagrion xanthomelas]]'') breeds in the anchialine pools while native insects perch on the nearby vegetation. Throughout the state, anchialine species are severely threatened by alien insects, habitat loss due to coastal development, and other human impacts.
Anchialine ponds are one of Hawaiis most threatened ecosystems. Anchialine pools are landlocked brackish ponds located close to the shoreline connected to the ocean via subterranean tunnels. Characterized by tidal fluctuations, these rare and fragile ponds are home to unusual plants and animals.

Formed by volcanic activity, these pools are home to a unique assemblage of invertebrate and algal species, some of which are known to exist only in this habitat. In the last 20 years, alien fish species have been introduced and/or invaded a majority of the pools. These alien species have gradually destroyed the ecological balance in many of the pools by eliminating many of unique endemic species.
==Koa== Punalu{{okina}}u has long been known for its koa (fish houses) where specific species of fish live in specific areas offshore. The pristine, spring fed waters of Punalu{{okina}}u mixing with the salt water of the ocean provide ideal habitat for a variety of fish that live in these naturally created koa. There are several koa just offshore from Punalu{{okina}}u still used by local fishermen. Each koa is identified by the species of fish that live there, including [[yellowfin tuna]] (ahi) and [[mackerel]] (ono, or [[wahoo]]). In the old days, Hawaiian families would feed the fish in the koa cooked [[taro]] and pumpkin and the fish, in return, would provide a constant source of protein.
==Development== A golf course on both sides of the Belt Road was built here by [[C. Brewer & Co.]] frm 1969-1972. A larger resort was proposed in 1986. After opposition, the plans were scaled back.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://oeqc.doh.hawaii.gov/Shared%20Documents/EA_and_EIS_Online_Library/Hawaii/1980s/1988-04-HA-FEIS-PUNALUU-RESORT-VOL-1.pdf |title=Final Environmental Impact Statement for Punalu{{okina}}u Resort Volume I |work=state of Hawaii web site |accessdate=2009-10-24 |date=April 1988 }}</ref> The project was partially built but abandoned. [[Spinner Dolphin]]s and [[Humpback Whale]]s can also be sighted offshore from Punalu{{okina}}u. Residents say such sightings are common. A rare sighting of a Hawaiian Monk Seal was reported at Punalu{{okina}}u in September 2006 near the boat ramp, and several known nesting sites of the endangered Hawksbill turtles are located along the Punalu{{okina}}u and Ninole area. Researchers estimate there are fewer than 80 nesting Hawksbill turtles in the Hawaiian islands, of which 67 nest on the island of Hawai{{okina}}i. More than half of the known nesting population statewide, 40 individuals nest along the southeast boundary of Hawai{{okina}}i Volcanoes National park to Waikapuna.
The threatened [[Green turtle]] or honu (Chelonia mydas) feeds on marine plants in shallow waters along the coastline such as Punalu{{okina}}u. Red seaweed, a favorite food of the Green turtle flourishes on the coral-encrusted rocks in the shallow waters of the bay and the turtles are found basking on the black sand beach despite the presence of beachgoers. Researchers with the National Marine Fisheries have been studying the Green turtle since 1982 along with groups of students. Systematic surveys have observed damselfly populations at Kw{{okina}}a, Hlea, Nnole, and Honu{{okina}}apo. The highest densities occur at the back of [[Estuary|estuarine]] [[Salt marsh|marsh]], at the mouth of Hlea and Nnole Streams, and at Kw{{okina}}a Springs.

These pools are rare and localized [[brackish water]]s along coastal lava flows that exhibit [[Tide|tidal]] fluctuations without a surface connection to the sea. There are several koa just offshore from Punalu{{okina}}u still used by local fishermen. Richardson Beach, is located just outside of Hilo, Hawaii, on the Big Island. The name Richardson comes from it's original owner, and builder of the still standing home there, Robert Richardson. Richardson was a direct decedent of King Kamehameha the Great, and at one time the Chief Detective of Honolulu before retiring to Hilo.
Today the beach is a public park, and the home is occupied and operated as the Richardson Ocean Center.
Richardson Beach is the only beach in Hilo with black sand.

[[Image:green_sands_beach.jpg|thumb|Green Sands Beach, view from cliff above, May 2007]]
'''Mahana Beach''' (also known as '''Green Sands Beach''') is a natural feature at [[Ka Lae|South Point]] on the [[Hawaii (island)|Island of Hawai{{okina}}i]] and one of only two green sand beaches in the [[United States]], the other being in [[Guam]]. The green sand gets its distinctive coloring from [[olivine]] crystals found in a nearby [[cinder cone]].
==Characteristics and formation==
Mahana Beach is located in a [[bay]] circled by [[Pu`u Mahana]], a [[cinder cone]] formed over 49,000 years ago<ref name="usgsorigins">{{cite web |title=The Origins of Pu{{okina}}u Mahana are not crystal clear |url=http://hvo.wr.usgs.gov/volcanowatch/2005/05_10_27.html |date=2005-10-27 |accessdate=2008-01-22}}</ref> and associated with the southwest rift of [[Mauna Loa]].
The cinder cone is rich in [[olivine]], a [[silicate]] mineral containing [[iron]] and [[magnesium]]. Commonly found in Hawaiian [[lava]] flows, this mineral is also known as "Hawaiian Diamond" and is found not only in [[periodot]] gems but also in [[Oahu|O{{okina}}ahu's]] famous [[Diamond Head]] landmark.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pubs.usgs.gov/gip/hawaii/page36.html |title=Eruptions of Hawaiian Volcanoes |accessdate=2008-01-22}}</ref> Since the formation of the cinder cone, the active [[waves|tidal action]] of the bay has pounded the shoreline, washing lighter [[black sand|volcanic sand]] and ash out to sea while leaving behind the heavier olivine crystals, giving the beach a distinctive green coloring.<ref name="usgsgreensand">{{cite web |title=Green Sand |url=http://geomaps.wr.usgs.gov/parks/coast/sand/greensand.html |accessdate=2008-01-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://volcano.und.nodak.edu/vwdocs/frequent_questions/grp5/question1428.html |title=How was the green sand beach on the Big Island, Hawaii formed? |accessdate=2008-01-22}}</ref> Although these crystals are eventually washed away as well, the constant erosion of the cinder cone ensures—eventually, however, the supply will run out and the beach will look like any other.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wrgis.wr.usgs.gov/parks/coast/sand/index.html |title=USGS - Green Sand Beach, Hawai{{okina}}i (Getting There) |accessdate=2008-01-22}}</ref>
The formation of the cinder cone is currently a point of contention, with some arguing that lava flowing into the sea was suddenly cooled (a [[Littoral zone|littoral]] cone) and others noting that the cone was most likely too far away from the ocean at the time of formation to make such an event possible.<ref name="usgsorigins" /> Regardless, the geologic history of the site can be seen in the rock surrounding the beach and bay, which are not subject to erosion and thus display geologic layers formed by previous eruptions, lava flows, and other volcanic events.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://geomaps.wr.usgs.gov/parks/coast/sand/gsand2.html |title=Green Sands Beach - The Beach |accessdate=2008-01-22}}</ref> In addition, the current patterns of erosion can be seen first-hand, as only the portions at the bottom of the cinder cone collapse have been subject to the waves and turned into green sand; the remaining portions appear gray.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://wrgis.wr.usgs.gov/parks/coast/sand/gsand3.html |title=Green Sand Beach - Slope |accessdate=2008-01-22}}</ref>
==Access==
The beach is located at [[Ka Lae|South Point]] on the [[Hawaii (island)|island of Hawai{{okina}}i]]. The cinder cone is rich in [[olivine]], a [[silicate]] mineral containing [[iron]] and [[magnesium]]. It is surrounded by [[pastureland]]s and is only accessible on foot or by using a vehicle equipped with [[4WD|four-wheel drive]].<ref name="frommers">{{cite web | last = Foster | first = Jeanette | title = Beaches | work = Frommer's Hawaii 2008 | publisher = [[Frommer's]] | date = 2007 | url = http://www.frommers.com/destinations/hawaiithebigisland/0008020389.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref> To actually reach the beach, an additional climb down the cinder cone is required.<ref name="frommers">{{cite web | last = Graber | first = Janna | title = In Search of Green: The Unusual Side of Hawaii's Big Island | publisher = Go World Travel Magazine | date = 2007 | url = http://www.goworldtravel.com/ex/aspx/articleGuid.%7BAB7491F2-C266-4C4D-8BF2-4B2C69319352%7D/xe/article.htm | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref><ref name="drbeach">{{cite web | last = Leatherman | first = Stephen P. | title = Big Island | publisher = Drbeach.org | date = 2007 | url = http://www.drbeach.org/drbeach/hawaii/beach_hawaiian_bigisland.htm | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref>

[[Image:Mahana snapshot.jpg|thumb|Looking over Mahana Beach]]
'''Mahana Beach''' (also known as ''Green Sands Beach'' and, erroneously, ''Pu{{okina}}u Mahana'') is a [[greensand|green sand]] beach located at [[Ka Lae|South Point]], in the [[Kau, Hawaii|Ka{{okina}}u district]] of the [[Hawaii (island)|island of Hawai{{okina}}i]]. One of only two [[green sand beach]]es in the [[United States]], the other being [[Talofofo Beach]] in [[Guam]],<ref name="westhawaiisand">{{cite web | last = Lucas | first = Carolyn | url = http://www.westhawaiitoday.com/articles/2006/06/13/local/local02.prt | title = What makes sand... A look at the science behind the scenic | publisher = West Hawaii Today | date = 2006-06-13 | accessdate = 2008-01-23 }}</ref> the beach gets distinctive coloring from [[olivine]] crystals found in a nearby [[cinder cone]].
==Characteristics== [[Image:Green Sands Mahana.jpg|right|thumb|100px|The green sand is more abundant at the bottom of the cinder cone.]] Mahana Beach is located in a [[bay]] circled by [[Puu Mahana|Pu{{okina}}u Mahana]], a [[cinder cone]] formed over 49,000 years ago<ref name="usgsorigins">{{cite web | title = The Origins of Pu{{okina}}u Mahana are not crystal clear | work = Hawaiian Volcano Observatory | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 2005-10-27 | url = http://hvo.wr.usgs.gov/volcanowatch/2005/05_10_27.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref> and associated with the southwest rift of [[Mauna Loa]]. Since its last eruption, the cinder cone has partially collapsed and been partially eroded by the ocean.
The cinder cone is rich in [[olivine]], a [[silicate]] mineral containing [[iron]] and [[magnesium]]. Commonly found in Hawaiian [[lava]] flows and one of the first crystals to form as [[magma]] temperatures rise,<ref name="westhawaiisand" /> olivine is also known as "Hawaiian Diamond" and is found not only in [[peridot]] gems but also in [[Oahu|O{{okina}}ahu's]] famous [[Diamond Head]] landmark.<ref>{{cite web | last = Tilling | first = Robert I. | coauthors = Christina Heliker, Thomas L. Wright | title = Eruptive Style: Powerful but Usually Benign | work = Eruptions of Hawaiian Volcanoes: Past, Present, and Future | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 1987 | url = http://pubs.usgs.gov/gip/hawaii/page36.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref> Since the formation and collapse of the cinder cone, the active [[waves|tidal action]] of the bay has pounded the shoreline, washing lighter [[black sand|volcanic sand]] and ash out to sea while leaving behind the heavier olivine crystals, giving the beach a distinctive green coloring.<ref name="usgsgreensand">{{cite web | title = Green Sand | work = Coastal Geology of the Parks | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 2004 | url = http://geomaps.wr.usgs.gov/parks/coast/sand/greensand.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Mattox | first = Steve | title = How was the green sand beach on the Big Island, Hawaii formed? | work = Volcano World | publisher = [[University of North Dakota]] | url = http://volcano.und.nodak.edu/vwdocs/frequent_questions/grp5/question1428.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref> Although these crystals are eventually washed away as well, the constant erosion of the cinder cone ensures a steady supply of sand for the forseeable future—eventually, however, the supply will run out and the beach will look like any other.<ref name="gettingthere">{{cite web | title = Green Sand Beach, Hawai{{okina}}i - Getting There | work = Coastal Geology of the Parks | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 2004 | url = http://wrgis.wr.usgs.gov/parks/coast/sand/index.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref>
The formation of the cinder cone is currently a point of contention, with some arguing that lava flowing into the sea was suddenly cooled (a [[Littoral zone|littoral]] cone) and others noting that the cone was most likely too far away from the ocean at the time of formation to make such an event possible.<ref name="usgsorigins"/> Regardless of how it was formed according to the [[United States Geological Survey]], the last lava flow in the area ended over 10,000 years ago, making the area one of the more stable features in the geologically turbulent Ka{{okina}}u region.<ref>{{cite web | work = Hawaiian Volcano Observatory | url = http://hvo.wr.usgs.gov/volcanowatch/1998/98_03_05.html | title = Natural hazards in the Ka{{okina}}u District | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 1998-03-05 | accessdate = 2008-01-23 }}</ref> As such, the geologic history of the site can be seen in the rock surrounding the beach and bay, which are not subject to erosion and thus display geologic layers formed by previous eruptions, lava flows, and other volcanic events.<ref name="thebeach">{{cite web | title = Green Sand Beach, Hawai{{okina}}i - The Beach | work = Coastal Geology of the Parks | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 2004 | url = http://geomaps.wr.usgs.gov/parks/coast/sand/gsand2.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref> In addition, the current patterns of erosion can be seen first-hand, as only the portions at the bottom of the cinder cone collapse have been subject to the waves and turned into green sand; the remaining portions appear gray.<ref name="slope">{{cite web | title = Green Sand Beach, Hawai{{okina}}i - Slope | work = Coastal Geology of the Parks | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 2004 | url = http://wrgis.wr.usgs.gov/parks/coast/sand/gsand3.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref>
{{-}} ==Green sand in space== [[Image:Green sand closeup 2.jpg|left|thumb|150px|Closeup of green sand from Mahana Beach]] In 2005, the [[Gemini Observatory|Gemini project]] observed the collision of [[Deep Impact (space mission)|Deep Impact]] with the [[comet]] [[9P/Tempel]]. By examining the aftermath of the collision in infrared, scientists were able to confirm that a portion of the material ejected was olivine crystals similar in shape and structure to the sand found at Mahana Beach, albeit smaller.<ref name="nasa_gemini">{{cite web | last = Bluck | first = John | work = [[NASA Ames Research Center]] | title = NASA Research Finds Green Sand Crystals Are in Comet Tempel 1 | publisher = [[NASA]] | url = http://www.nasa.gov/centers/ames/research/exploringtheuniverse/comettemple1.html | date = 2005-09-15 | accessdate = 2008-01-24 }}</ref> Although the comet [[Hale-Bopp]] routinely sheds green crystals from its surface, this was the first time that green sand was confirmed to exist within a comet already "cooked" by the sun.
{{-}}
==Access== The beach is located at [[Ka Lae|South Point]] on the [[Hawaii (island)|island of Hawai{{okina}}i]]. It is surrounded by [[pastureland]]s and is only accessible on foot or by using a vehicle equipped with [[4WD|four-wheel drive]].<ref name="frommers">{{cite web | last = Foster | first = Jeanette | title = Beaches | work = Frommer's Hawaii 2008 | publisher = [[Frommer's]] | date = 2007 | url = http://www.frommers.com/destinations/hawaiithebigisland/0008020389.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref> To actually reach the beach, an additional climb down the cinder cone is required.<ref name="frommers">{{cite web | last = Graber | first = Janna | title = In Search of Green: The Unusual Side of Hawaii's Big Island | publisher = Go World Travel Magazine | date = 2007 | url = http://www.goworldtravel.com/ex/aspx/articleGuid.%7BAB7491F2-C266-4C4D-8BF2-4B2C69319352%7D/xe/article.htm | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref><ref name="drbeach">{{cite web | last = Leatherman | first = Stephen P. | title = Big Island | publisher = Drbeach.org | date = 2007 | url = http://www.drbeach.org/drbeach/hawaii/beach_hawaiian_bigisland.htm | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref>

[[Image:Mahana snapshot.jpg|thumb|Looking over Mahana Beach]]
'''Mahana Beach''' (also known as ''Green Sands Beach'' and, erroneously, ''Pu{{okina}}u Mahana'') is a [[greensand|green sand]] beach located at [[Ka Lae|South Point]], in the [[Kau, Hawaii|Ka{{okina}}u district]] of the [[Hawaii (island)|island of Hawai{{okina}}i]]. One of only two [[green sand beach]]es in the [[United States]], the other being [[Talofofo Beach]] in [[Guam]],<ref name="westhawaiisand">{{cite web | last = Lucas | first = Carolyn | url = http://www.westhawaiitoday.com/articles/2006/06/13/local/local02.prt | title = What makes sand... A look at the science behind the scenic | publisher = West Hawaii Today | date = 2006-06-13 | accessdate = 2008-01-23 }}</ref> the beach gets distinctive coloring from [[olivine]] crystals found in a nearby [[cinder cone]].
==Characteristics== [[Image:Green Sands Mahana.jpg|right|thumb|100px|The green sand is more abundant at the bottom of the cinder cone.]] Mahana Beach is located in a [[bay]] circled by [[Puu Mahana|Pu{{okina}}u Mahana]], a [[cinder cone]] formed over 49,000 years ago<ref name="usgsorigins">{{cite web | title = The Origins of Pu{{okina}}u Mahana are not crystal clear | work = Hawaiian Volcano Observatory | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 2005-10-27 | url = http://hvo.wr.usgs.gov/volcanowatch/2005/05_10_27.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref> and associated with the southwest rift of [[Mauna Loa]]. Since its last eruption, the cinder cone has partially collapsed and been partially eroded by the ocean.
The cinder cone is rich in [[olivine]], a [[silicate]] mineral containing [[iron]] and [[magnesium]], also known as [[peridot]] when of gem quality. Olivine is a common mineral component of Hawaiian [[lava]]s and one of the first crystals to form as [[magma]] cools.<ref name="westhawaiisand" /> Olivine is locally known as "Hawaiian Diamond" and is notably found in [[Oahu|O{{okina}}ahu's]] famous [[Diamond Head]] landmark.<ref>{{cite web | last = Tilling | first = Robert I. | coauthors = Christina Heliker, Thomas L. Wright | title = Eruptive Style: Powerful but Usually Benign | work = Eruptions of Hawaiian Volcanoes: Past, Present, and Future | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 1987 | url = http://pubs.usgs.gov/gip/hawaii/page36.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref> The source of the green coloration of the beach sands is due to the olivine crystals which are winnowed from the eroding headland by the action of the sea. Olivine, being denser and tougher than the ash fragments, glass and black [[pyroxene]] of the rest of the rocks and lava flows, tends to accumulate on the beach whereas the usual [[black sand|volcanic sand]] is swept out to sea.<ref name="usgsgreensand">{{cite web | title = Green Sand | work = Coastal Geology of the Parks | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 2004 | url = http://geomaps.wr.usgs.gov/parks/coast/sand/greensand.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Mattox | first = Steve | title = How was the green sand beach on the Big Island, Hawaii formed? | work = Volcano World | publisher = [[University of North Dakota]] | url = http://volcano.und.nodak.edu/vwdocs/frequent_questions/grp5/question1428.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref> Although these crystals are eventually washed away as well, the constant erosion of the cinder cone ensures a steady supply of sand for the forseeable future—eventually, however, the supply will run out and the beach will look like any other.<ref name="gettingthere">{{cite web | title = Green Sand Beach, Hawai{{okina}}i - Getting There | work = Coastal Geology of the Parks | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 2004 | url = http://wrgis.wr.usgs.gov/parks/coast/sand/index.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref>
The formation of the cinder cone is currently a point of contention, with some arguing that lava flowing into the sea was suddenly cooled, forming an edifice on the coastline (a [[cinder cone|littoral cone]]) and others noting that the cone was most likely too far away from the ocean at the time of formation to make such an event possible.<ref name="usgsorigins"/> Regardless of how it was formed according to the [[United States Geological Survey]], the last lava flow in the area ended over 10,000 years ago, making the area one of the more stable features in the geologically turbulent Ka{{okina}}u region.<ref>{{cite web | work = Hawaiian Volcano Observatory | url = http://hvo.wr.usgs.gov/volcanowatch/1998/98_03_05.html | title = Natural hazards in the Ka{{okina}}u District | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 1998-03-05 | accessdate = 2008-01-23 }}</ref> As such, the geologic history of the site can be seen in the rock surrounding the beach and bay, which are not subject to erosion and thus display geologic layers formed by previous eruptions, lava flows, and other volcanic events.<ref name="thebeach">{{cite web | title = Green Sand Beach, Hawai{{okina}}i - The Beach | work = Coastal Geology of the Parks | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 2004 | url = http://geomaps.wr.usgs.gov/parks/coast/sand/gsand2.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref> In addition, the current patterns of erosion can be seen first-hand, as only the portions at the bottom of the cinder cone collapse have been subject to the waves and turned into green sand; the remaining portions appear gray.<ref name="slope">{{cite web | title = Green Sand Beach, Hawai{{okina}}i - Slope | work = Coastal Geology of the Parks | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 2004 | url = http://wrgis.wr.usgs.gov/parks/coast/sand/gsand3.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref>
{{-}}
==Green sand in space== [[Image:Green sand closeup 2.jpg|left|thumb|150px|Closeup of green sand from Mahana Beach]] In 2005, the [[Gemini Observatory|Gemini project]] observed the collision of [[Deep Impact (space mission)|Deep Impact]] with the [[comet]] [[9P/Tempel]]. By examining the aftermath of the collision in infrared, scientists were able to confirm that a portion of the material ejected was olivine crystals similar in shape and structure to the sand found at Mahana Beach, albeit smaller.<ref name="nasa_gemini">{{cite web | last = Bluck | first = John | work = [[NASA Ames Research Center]] | title = NASA Research Finds Green Sand Crystals Are in Comet Tempel 1 | publisher = [[NASA]] | url = http://www.nasa.gov/centers/ames/research/exploringtheuniverse/comettemple1.html | date = 2005-09-15 | accessdate = 2008-01-24 }}</ref> Although the comet [[Hale-Bopp]] routinely sheds green crystals from its surface, this was the first time that green sand was confirmed to exist within a comet already "cooked" by the sun.
{{-}}
==Access== The beach is located at [[Ka Lae|South Point]] on the [[Hawaii (island)|island of Hawai{{okina}}i]]. It is surrounded by [[pastureland]]s and is only accessible on foot or by using a vehicle equipped with [[4WD|four-wheel drive]].<ref name="frommers">{{cite web | last = Foster | first = Jeanette | title = Beaches | work = Frommer's Hawaii 2008 | publisher = [[Frommer's]] | date = 2007 | url = http://www.frommers.com/destinations/hawaiithebigisland/0008020389.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref> To actually reach the beach, an additional climb down the cinder cone is required.<ref name="frommers">{{cite web | last = Graber | first = Janna | title = In Search of Green: The Unusual Side of Hawaii's Big Island | publisher = Go World Travel Magazine | date = 2007 | url = http://www.goworldtravel.com/ex/aspx/articleGuid.%7BAB7491F2-C266-4C4D-8BF2-4B2C69319352%7D/xe/article.htm | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref><ref name="drbeach">{{cite web | last = Leatherman | first = Stephen P. | title = Big Island | publisher = Drbeach.org | date = 2007 | url = http://www.drbeach.org/drbeach/hawaii/beach_hawaiian_bigisland.htm | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}

Olivine is a common mineral component of Hawaiian [[lava]]s and one of the first crystals to form as [[magma]] cools.<ref name="westhawaiisand" /> Olivine is locally known as "Hawaiian Diamond" and is notably found in [[Oahu|O{{okina}}ahu's]] famous [[Diamond Head]] landmark.<ref>{{cite web | last = Tilling | first = Robert I. | coauthors = Christina Heliker, Thomas L. Wright | title = Eruptive Style: Powerful but Usually Benign | work = Eruptions of Hawaiian Volcanoes: Past, Present, and Future | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 1987 | url = http://pubs.usgs.gov/gip/hawaii/page36.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref> The source of the green coloration of the beach sands is due to the olivine crystals which are winnowed from the eroding headland by the action of the sea. Olivine, being denser and tougher than the ash fragments, glass and black [[pyroxene]] of the rest of the rocks and lava flows, tends to accumulate on the beach whereas the usual [[black sand|volcanic sand]] is swept out to sea.<ref name="usgsgreensand">{{cite web | title = Green Sand | work = Coastal Geology of the Parks | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 2004 | url = http://geomaps.wr.usgs.gov/parks/coast/sand/greensand.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Mattox | first = Steve | title = How was the green sand beach on the Big Island, Hawaii formed? | work = Volcano World | publisher = [[University of North Dakota]] | url = http://volcano.und.nodak.edu/vwdocs/frequent_questions/grp5/question1428.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref> Although these crystals are eventually washed away as well, the constant erosion of the cinder cone ensures a steady supply of sand for the forseeable future—eventually, however, the supply will run out and the beach will look like any other.<ref name="gettingthere">{{cite web | title = Green Sand Beach, Hawai{{okina}}i - Getting There | work = Coastal Geology of the Parks | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 2004 | url = http://wrgis.wr.usgs.gov/parks/coast/sand/index.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref>

{{-}}

{{-}}
==Access== The beach is located at [[Ka Lae|South Point]] on the [[Hawaii (island)|island of Hawai{{okina}}i]]. It is surrounded by [[pastureland]]s and is only accessible on foot or by using a vehicle equipped with [[4WD|four-wheel drive]].<ref name="frommers">{{cite web | last = Foster | first = Jeanette | title = Beaches | work = Frommer's Hawaii 2008 | publisher = [[Frommer's]] | date = 2007 | url = http://www.frommers.com/destinations/hawaiithebigisland/0008020389.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref> To actually reach the beach, an additional climb down the cinder cone is required.<ref name="frommers">{{cite web | last = Graber | first = Janna | title = In Search of Green: The Unusual Side of Hawaii's Big Island | publisher = Go World Travel Magazine | date = 2007 | url = http://www.goworldtravel.com/ex/aspx/articleGuid.%7BAB7491F2-C266-4C4D-8BF2-4B2C69319352%7D/xe/article.htm | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref><ref name="drbeach">{{cite web | last = Leatherman | first = Stephen P. | title = Big Island | publisher = Drbeach.org | date = 2007 | url = http://www.drbeach.org/drbeach/hawaii/beach_hawaiian_bigisland.htm | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref>

Olivine, being denser and tougher than the ash fragments, glass and black [[pyroxene]] of the rest of the rocks and lava flows, tends to accumulate on the beach whereas the usual [[black sand|volcanic sand]] is swept out to sea.<ref name="usgsgreensand">{{cite web | title = Green Sand | work = Coastal Geology of the Parks | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 2004 | url = http://geomaps.wr.usgs.gov/parks/coast/sand/greensand.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Mattox | first = Steve | title = How was the green sand beach on the Big Island, Hawaii formed? | work = Volcano World | publisher = [[University of North Dakota]] | url = http://volcano.und.nodak.edu/vwdocs/frequent_questions/grp5/question1428.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref> Although these crystals are eventually washed away as well, the constant erosion of the cinder cone ensures a steady supply of sand for the forseeable future—eventually, however, the supply will run out and the beach will look like any other.<ref name="gettingthere">{{cite web | title = Green Sand Beach, Hawai{{okina}}i - Getting There | work = Coastal Geology of the Parks | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 2004 | url = http://wrgis.wr.usgs.gov/parks/coast/sand/index.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref>
The formation of the cinder cone is currently a point of contention, with some arguing that lava flowing into the sea was suddenly cooled, forming an edifice on the coastline (a [[cinder cone|littoral cone]]) and others noting that the cone was most likely too far away from the ocean at the time of formation to make such an event possible.<ref name="usgsorigins"/> Regardless of how it was formed according to the [[United States Geological Survey]], the last lava flow in the area ended over 10,000 years ago, making the area one of the more stable features in the geologically turbulent Ka{{okina}}u region.<ref>{{cite web | work = Hawaiian Volcano Observatory | url = http://hvo.wr.usgs.gov/volcanowatch/1998/98_03_05.html | title = Natural hazards in the Ka{{okina}}u District | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 1998-03-05 | accessdate = 2008-01-23 }}</ref> As such, the geologic history of the site can be seen in the rock surrounding the beach and bay, which are not subject to erosion and thus display geologic layers formed by previous eruptions, lava flows, and other volcanic events.<ref name="thebeach">{{cite web | title = Green Sand Beach, Hawai{{okina}}i - The Beach | work = Coastal Geology of the Parks | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 2004 | url = http://geomaps.wr.usgs.gov/parks/coast/sand/gsand2.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref> In addition, the current patterns of erosion can be seen first-hand, as only the portions at the bottom of the cinder cone collapse have been subject to the waves and turned into green sand; the remaining portions appear gray.<ref name="slope">{{cite web | title = Green Sand Beach, Hawai{{okina}}i - Slope | work = Coastal Geology of the Parks | publisher = [[USGS]] | date = 2004 | url = http://wrgis.wr.usgs.gov/parks/coast/sand/gsand3.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref>
{{-}}
==Green sand in space== [[Image:Green sand closeup 2.jpg|left|thumb|150px|Closeup of green sand from Papakolea Beach]] In 2005, the [[Gemini Observatory|Gemini project]] observed the collision of [[Deep Impact (space mission)|Deep Impact]] with the [[comet]] [[9P/Tempel]]. By examining the aftermath of the collision in infrared, scientists were able to confirm that a portion of the material ejected was olivine crystals similar in shape and structure to the sand found at Papakolea Beach, albeit smaller.<ref name="nasa_gemini">{{cite web | last = Bluck | first = John | work = [[NASA Ames Research Center]] | title = NASA Research Finds Green Sand Crystals Are in Comet Tempel 1 | publisher = [[NASA]] | url = http://www.nasa.gov/centers/ames/research/exploringtheuniverse/comettemple1.html | date = 2005-09-15 | accessdate = 2008-01-24 }}</ref> Although the comet [[Hale-Bopp]] routinely sheds green crystals from its surface, this was the first time that green sand was confirmed to exist within a comet already "cooked" by the sun.
{{-}}
==Access== The beach is located at [[Ka Lae|South Point]] on the [[Hawaii (island)|island of Hawai{{okina}}i]]. It is surrounded by [[pasture|pasturelands]] and is only accessible on foot or by using a vehicle equipped with [[4WD|four-wheel drive]].<ref name="frommers">{{cite web | last = Foster | first = Jeanette | title = Beaches | work = Frommer's Hawaii 2008 | publisher = [[Frommer's]] | date = 2007 | url = http://www.frommers.com/destinations/hawaiithebigisland/0008020389.html | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref> To actually reach the beach, an additional climb down the cinder cone is required.<ref name="frommers">{{cite web | last = Graber | first = Janna | title = In Search of Green: The Unusual Side of Hawaii's Big Island | publisher = Go World Travel Magazine | date = 2007 | url = http://www.goworldtravel.com/ex/aspx/articleGuid.%7BAB7491F2-C266-4C4D-8BF2-4B2C69319352%7D/xe/article.htm | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref><ref name="drbeach">{{cite web | last = Leatherman | first = Stephen P. | title = Big Island | publisher = Drbeach.org | date = 2007 | url = http://www.drbeach.org/drbeach/hawaii/beach_hawaiian_bigisland.htm | accessdate = 2008-01-22 }}</ref>

'''Kamilo Beach''' is situated at the southernmost tip of the [[Big Island]], of [[Hawaii]], in the [[Pacific Ocean]].
It is best known for its accumulation of debris from the [[Great_Pacific_Garbage_Patch|Great Pacific Garbage Patch]].
=History= This once pristine beach used to be a location where native Hawaiians would to come to find large logs for [[dug-out]] canoes which drifted ashore from the [[Pacific Northwest]]. It was also a location where people who were lost at sea might eventually wash ashore.<ref>http://www.khnl.com/Global/story.asp?S=7334574</ref><ref>http://www.latimes.com/news/local/oceans/la-me-ocean2aug02,0,3130914.story?page=2</ref>
Around 1960, Kamilo beach was still free of man-made debris, with the exception of a few tires. It was then a place where [[driftwood]], used for sculptures, was gathered by local artists.<ref> http://www.mindfully.org/Water/2006/Sea-Plague-Plastic2aug06.htm</ref>
=Location= Kamilo Beach is approximately 5 miles long, and is located in remote area of [[Ka'u]], at the south tip of the [[Big Island]].
=Description= Also known as ''Plastic Beach'', in terms of debris, Kamilo Beach is the dirtiest beach in the [[Hawaiian Islands]], and possibly the dirtiest beach in the world.<ref>http://sixtyminutes.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=598914</ref> The crescent shaped beach is an accumulation zone for [[plastic]] trash. The debris is forced onto the beach by constant [[trade winds]] and converging currents.
=Debris= The accumulated garbage on Kamilo Beach consists of 90% plastic.<ref>BBC, Natural World, Message in the Waves - Hawaii</ref> Various household objects comprise the bulk of the trash including: toothbrushes, pens, cigarette lighters, plastic caps and bottles, cups, keyboards, DVDs, plates, combs, knives, forks, babies' dummies, toys, TVs, sandwich wrappers, lipsticks, hair brushes, pens, shoes, plugs, and clocks.<ref> http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-494758/How-womans-battle-save-dying-albatross-spawned-national-campaign-ban-plastic-bags.html</ref>
Part of the debris is made from plastic pellets, either [[pre-production]] or created from larger plastic items breaking down into smaller pieces. These smaller pieces are referred to as 'plastic sand', and now exceed the volume of the beach's natural sand.<ref>http://www.khnl.com/Global/story.asp?s=7334574</ref>
{| class=wikitable |- | colspan=3 align=center|'''Top 10 items collected from beaches and ocean in Hawaii during a 2005 cleanup'''<ref>http://archives.starbulletin.com/2007/11/11/news/story02.html</ref> |- ! Debris ! Amount ! Percentage of total
Total 97,178 81.8% |- align=center | Cigarettes | 39,913 | 33.6% | |- align=center | Caps and lids | 14,253 | 12% | |- align=center | Food wrappers | 10,955 | 9.2% | |- align=center | Glass bottles | 8,285 | 7% | |- align=center | Cups, plates, utensils | 5,379 | 4.5% | |- align=center | Plastic bottles | 3,824 | 3.2% | |- align=center | Cans | 3,518 | 3% | |- align=center | Fishing line | 3,456 | 2.9% | |- align=center | Straws, stirers | 2,945 | 2.5% | |- align=center | Total | 97,178 | 81.8% | |- align=center |}
=Cleanup efforts= At least three major cleanup efforts have taken place in recent years. Prior to that, the debris was 8 to 10 feet high in some places.
In October 2007, Charles Moore, head of the [[Algalita Research Foundation]] in [[Long Beach], California]], and volunteers from the [[Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign]], Hawaii, joined [[University_of_Hawaii_at_Hilo|University of Hawaii, Hilo]] students in an effort to cleanup Kamilo Beach.<ref> http://archives.starbulletin.com/2007/11/11/news/story02.html</ref>
The most recent effort was organized by Bill Gilmartin, a retired [[wildlife biologist]].
=References= <references />
=External links= *[http://www.b-e-a-c-h.org b-e-a-c-h] *[http://www.greatgarbagepatch.org/ Great Garbage Patch site]

{{coord|18|54|N|155|40|W|type:city_region:US|display=title}} [[Image:HIMap-doton-Naalehu.PNG|thumb|230px|right|Kamilo Beach, Hawai'i]] '''Kamilo Beach''' is situated at the southernmost tip of the [[Big Island]], of [[Hawai'i]], in the [[Pacific Ocean]].
It is best known for its accumulation of [[debris]] from the [[Great_Pacific_Garbage_Patch|Great Pacific Garbage Patch]].
==History== This once pristine beach used to be a location where [[Native Hawaiians]] would to come to find large evergreen logs for [[dug-out]] canoes which drifted ashore from the [[Pacific Northwest]]. It was also a location where people who were lost at sea might eventually wash ashore.<ref>http://www.khnl.com/Global/story.asp?S=7334574</ref><ref>http://www.latimes.com/news/local/oceans/la-me-ocean2aug02,0,3130914.story?page=2</ref>
Around 1960, Kamilo beach was still free of man-made debris, with the exception of a few tires. It was then a place where [[driftwood]], used for sculptures, was gathered by local artists.<ref> http://www.mindfully.org/Water/2006/Sea-Plague-Plastic2aug06.htm</ref>
==Location== Kamilo Beach is approximately 450 meters long, and is located in remote area of [[Ka'u]], at the south tip of the [[Big Island]].
==Description== Kamilo Beach is one of many beaches on the Hawaiian islands that receives large amounts of debris from the [[Great Pacific Garbage Patch]]. Also known as ''Plastic Beach'', in terms of debris, Kamilo Beach is by far the dirtiest beach on the [[Hawaiian Islands]], and one of the dirtiest beaches in the world.<ref>http://sixtyminutes.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=598914</ref>
The [[crescent]] shaped beach is an accumulation zone for [[plastic]] trash. The debris is forced onto the beach by constant [[trade winds]] and converging [[currents]].
==Debris== The accumulated garbage which covers Kamilo Beach, and an adjacent 4.5 kilometers of shorline, consists of 90% plastic.<ref>BBC, Natural World, Message in the Waves - Hawai'i</ref> Although some of the items comprising the trash are household products, the vast majority are fishing related such as nets, rope, eel cones, oyster spacers, buoys, crates, and baskets.
Part of the debris is made from plastic pellets, either [[pre-production]] or created from larger plastic items breaking down into smaller pieces. These smaller pieces are referred to as 'plastic sand', and now exceed the volume of the beach's natural sand.<ref>http://www.khnl.com/Global/story.asp?s=7334574</ref>
==Environmental impact== [[Image: Albatross_chick_plastic.jpg|thumb|275px|right|A young bird has been fed plastic by its parents and was unable to eject it, resulting in death by either starvation or choking.]] [[Wildlife]] in the area has suffered significant damage due to the garbage on Kamilo beach and floating off shore.
Fishing debris such as discarded [[Fishing net|nets]] and fishing lines, traps, strangles, or drowns birds and [[sea mammals]]. Birds die from ingesting large pieces of plastic, notably young birds fed by their parents. [[Sea turtles]] mistake plastic bags for [[jellyfish]] and choke.<ref>http://a.abcnews.com/Technology/Story?id=4528488&page=2</ref>
Some types of plastic such as [[bisphenol A]] (BPA), [[DEHP]], [[phthalates]], and [[styrene]], leech [[carcinogenic]] or poisonous [[chemicals]] when they break down. Others absorb [[toxins]] such as [[DDT]] and [[PCB]]s from their surroundings. When consumed, these toxins are then absorbed by the animal.<ref>http://honoluluweekly.com/diary/2007/12/sea-of-plastic/</ref>
==Cleanup efforts== At least three major cleanup efforts have taken place in recent years. Prior to that, the debris was 8 to 10 feet high in some places.<ref>http://www.mindfully.org/Water/2006/Sea-Plague-Plastic2aug06.htm</ref>
In February 2006, the [[Hawai'i Wildlife Fund]] organized 120 volunteers, who removed 400 garbage bags of debris and up to 10 tons of fishing nets.<ref>http://www.pbase.com/charleswilliam3/beach_cleanup&gcmd=add_comment</ref>

{{coord|18|54|N|155|40|W|type:city_region:US|display=title}} [[Image:HIMap-doton-Naalehu.PNG|thumb|230px|right|Kamilo Beach, Hawai'i]] '''Kamilo Beach''' is situated at the southernmost tip of the [[Big Island]], of [[Hawai'i]], in the [[Pacific Ocean]].
It is best known for its accumulation of [[debris]] from the [[Great_Pacific_Garbage_Patch|Great Pacific Garbage Patch]].
==History== This once pristine beach used to be a location where [[Native Hawaiians]] would to come to find large evergreen logs for [[dug-out]] canoes which drifted ashore from the [[Pacific Northwest]]. It was also a location where people who were lost at sea might eventually wash ashore.<ref>[http://www.khnl.com/Global/story.asp?S=7334574 KHNL NBC 8 Honolulu Hawaii |Big Island Beach Attracts Plastic Trash<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.latimes.com/news/local/oceans/la-me-ocean2aug02,0,3130914.story?page=2 Plague of Plastic Chokes the Seas - Los Angeles Times<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Around 1960, Kamilo beach was still free of man-made debris, with the exception of a few tires. It was then a place where [[driftwood]], used for sculptures, was gathered by local artists.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.mindfully.org/Water/2006/Sea-Plague-Plastic2aug06.htm Plague of Plastic Chokes the Seas: On Midway Atoll, 40% of albatross chicks die, their bellies full of trash. Swirling masses of drifting debris pollute remote beaches and sna...<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Location== Kamilo Beach is approximately 450 meters long, and is located in remote area of [[Kau, Hawaii|Ka{{okina}}u]], at the south tip of the [[Big Island]].
==Description== Kamilo Beach is one of many beaches on the Hawaiian islands that receives large amounts of debris from the [[Great Pacific Garbage Patch]]. Also known as ''Plastic Beach'', in terms of debris, Kamilo Beach is by far the dirtiest beach on the [[Hawaiian Islands]], and one of the dirtiest beaches in the world.<ref>[http://sixtyminutes.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=598914 Seas of Shame<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The [[crescent]] shaped beach is an accumulation zone for [[plastic]] trash. The debris is forced onto the beach by constant [[trade winds]] and converging [[currents]].
==Debris== The accumulated garbage which covers Kamilo Beach, and an adjacent 4.5 kilometers of shorline, consists of 90% plastic.<ref>BBC, Natural World, Message in the Waves - Hawai'i</ref> Although some of the items comprising the trash are household products, the vast majority are fishing related such as nets, rope, eel cones, oyster spacers, buoys, crates, and baskets.
Part of the debris is made from plastic pellets, either [[pre-production]] or created from larger plastic items breaking down into smaller pieces. These smaller pieces are referred to as 'plastic sand', and now exceed the volume of the beach's natural sand.<ref>[http://www.khnl.com/Global/story.asp?s=7334574 KHNL NBC 8 Honolulu Hawaii |Big Island Beach Attracts Plastic Trash<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Environmental impact== [[Image: Albatross_chick_plastic.jpg|thumb|275px|right|A young bird has been fed plastic by its parents and was unable to eject it, resulting in death by either starvation or choking.]] [[Wildlife]] in the area has suffered significant damage due to the garbage on Kamilo beach and floating off shore.
Fishing debris such as discarded [[Fishing net|nets]] and fishing lines, traps, strangles, or drowns birds and [[sea mammals]]. Birds die from ingesting large pieces of plastic, notably young birds fed by their parents. [[Sea turtles]] mistake plastic bags for [[jellyfish]] and choke.<ref>[http://a.abcnews.com/Technology/Story?id=4528488&page=2 ABC News: Landfill in the Sea<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Some types of plastic such as [[bisphenol A]] (BPA), [[DEHP]], [[phthalates]], and [[styrene]], leech [[carcinogenic]] or poisonous [[chemicals]] when they break down. Others absorb [[toxins]] such as [[DDT]] and [[PCB]]s from their surroundings. When consumed, these toxins are then absorbed by the animal.<ref>[http://honoluluweekly.com/diary/2007/12/sea-of-plastic/ Sea of plastic :: Honolulu Weekly<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Cleanup efforts== At least three major cleanup efforts have taken place in recent years. Prior to that, the debris was 8 to 10 feet high in some places.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
In February 2006, the [[Hawaii Wildlife Fund|Hawai{{okina}}i Wildlife Fund]] organized 120 volunteers, who removed 400 garbage bags of debris and up to 10 tons of fishing nets.<ref>[http://www.pbase.com/charleswilliam3/beach_cleanup&gcmd=add_comment Hawaii Wildlife Fund - South Point Beach Cleanup 2/06 Photo Gallery by CW Lawrence at pbase.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In October 2007, Charles Moore, head of the [[Algalita Research Foundation]] in [[Long Beach]], California]], and volunteers from the [[Beach Environmental Awareness campaign Hawaii|Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign Hawai{[okina}}i]], joined [[University of Hawaii at Hilo|University of Hawai{{okina}}i, Hilo]] students in an effort to cleanup Kamilo Beach.<ref>http://archives.starbulletin.com/2007/11/11/news/story02.html</ref>
A clean up on November, 2007 removed more than 4 million pieces of plastic from the beach.
The beach has never been fully cleared of debris because the actual amount of garbage itself makes access difficult.

Also known as ''Plastic Beach'', in terms of debris, Kamilo Beach is by far the dirtiest beach on the [[Hawaiian Islands]], and one of the dirtiest beaches in the world.<ref>[http://sixtyminutes.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=598914 Seas of Shame<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The [[crescent]] shaped beach is an accumulation zone for [[plastic]] trash. The debris is forced onto the beach by constant [[trade winds]] and converging [[currents]].
==Debris== The accumulated garbage which covers Kamilo Beach, and an adjacent 4.5 kilometers of shoreline, consists of 90% plastic.<ref>BBC, Natural World, Message in the Waves - Hawai'i</ref> Although some of the items comprising the trash are household products, the vast majority are fishing related such as nets, rope, eel cones, oyster spacers, buoys, crates, and baskets.
Part of the debris is made from plastic pellets, either [[pre-production]] or created from larger plastic items breaking down into smaller pieces. These smaller pieces are referred to as 'plastic sand', and now exceed the volume of the beach's natural sand.<ref>[http://www.khnl.com/Global/story.asp?s=7334574 KHNL NBC 8 Honolulu Hawaii |Big Island Beach Attracts Plastic Trash<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Environmental impact== [[Image: Albatross_chick_plastic.jpg|thumb|275px|right|A young bird has been fed plastic by its parents and was unable to eject it, resulting in death by either starvation or choking.]] [[Wildlife]] in the area has suffered significant damage due to the garbage on Kamilo beach and floating off shore.
Fishing debris such as discarded [[Fishing net|nets]] and fishing lines, traps, strangles, or drowns birds and [[sea mammals]]. Birds die from ingesting large pieces of plastic, notably young birds fed by their parents. [[Sea turtles]] mistake plastic bags for [[jellyfish]] and choke.<ref>[http://a.abcnews.com/Technology/Story?id=4528488&page=2 ABC News: Landfill in the Sea<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Some types of plastic such as [[bisphenol A]] (BPA), [[DEHP]], [[phthalates]], and [[styrene]], leech [[carcinogenic]] or poisonous [[chemicals]] when they break down. Others absorb [[toxins]] such as [[DDT]] and [[PCB]]s from their surroundings. When consumed, these toxins are then absorbed by the animal.<ref>[http://honoluluweekly.com/diary/2007/12/sea-of-plastic/ Sea of plastic :: Honolulu Weekly<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Cleanup efforts== At least three major cleanup efforts have taken place in recent years. Prior to that, the debris was 8 to 10 feet high in some places.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
Efforts to clean up marine debris from Kamilo beach have included those by Hawai`i Wildlife Fund and Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign Hawai`i. In February 2006, the Hawaii Wildlife Fund organized 120 volunteers, who removed 400 garbage bags of debris and up to 10 tons of fishing nets.<ref>http://www.pbase.com/charleswilliam3/beach_cleanup&gcmd=add_comment Hawaii Wildlife Fund - South Point Beach Cleanup 2/06 Photo Gallery by CW Lawrence at pbase.com</ref>
In November 2007, Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign Hawai`i volunteers removed more than 4 million pieces of plastic from Kamilo Beach.

{{coord|18|54|N|155|40|W|type:city_region:US|display=title}} [[Image:Kamilo_Beach2_Courtesy_Algalita_dot_org.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Kamilo Beach, Hawaii]] '''Kamilo Beach''' (literally, ''the twisting'' in [[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian]]) is a beach located on the southeast coast of the island of [[Hawaii (island)|Hawaii]]. It is known for its accumulation of [[marine debris]] from the [[Great_Pacific_Garbage_Patch|Great Pacific Garbage Patch]].<ref>{{cite news | last = Sarhangi | first = Sheila | title = Getting Trashed | publisher = ''[[Honolulu Magazine]]'' | date = July 2008 | url = http://www.honolulumagazine.com/Honolulu-Magazine/July-2008/Getting-Trashed/ | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref>
==History== In ancient times, Kamilo Beach was a location where [[Native Hawaiians]] would go to find large evergreen logs, drifted ashore from the [[Pacific Northwest]], for building [[dug-out]] canoes. It was also a location where those who were lost at sea might eventually wash ashore.<ref name=Dashefsky>{{cite news | last = Dashefsky | first = Howard | title = Big Island Beach Attracts Plastic Trash | work = KHNL NBC 8 Honolulu Hawaii | publisher = ''[[KHNL]]'' | date = 2007-11-09 | url = http://www.khnl.com/Global/story.asp?S=7334574 | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref><ref name=Weiss>{{cite news | last = Weiss | first = Kenneth R. | title = Plague of Plastic Chokes the Seas | work = Part 4: Altered Oceans | publisher = ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' | date = 2007-11-09 | url = http://www.latimes.com/news/local/oceans/la-me-ocean2aug02,0,71579,full.story | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref>
Around 1960, Kamilo Beach was still free of man-made debris, with the exception of a few tires. It was then a place where [[driftwood]], used for sculptures, was gathered by local artists.<ref name=Weiss/>
==Description== [[Image:HIMap-doton-Naalehu.PNG|thumb|250px|right|Location of Kamilo Beach on the island of Hawaii.]] Kamilo Beach is approximately 450 meters long, and is located on the southeast coast of the [[Kau, Hawaii|Ka{{okina}}u District]] on the island of Hawaii.
Kamilo Beach is one of many beaches in the [[Hawaiian Islands]] that receives large amounts of debris from the [[Great Pacific Garbage Patch]]. Also known as ''Plastic Beach'', Kamilo Beach is by far the dirtiest beach in the Hawaiian Islands in terms of amount of debris, and is considered one of the dirtiest beaches in the world.<ref>[http://sixtyminutes.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=598914 Seas of Shame<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The [[crescent]]-shaped beach is an accumulation zone for [[plastic]] trash. The debris is forced onto the beach by constant [[Trade wind|trade winds]] and converging [[Ocean current|ocean currents]].
==Debris== The accumulated garbage that covers Kamilo Beach and an adjacent 4.5 kilometers of shoreline consists of 90% plastic.<ref>BBC, Natural World, Message in the Waves - Hawai'i</ref> Although some of the items comprising the trash are household products, the vast majority are fishing related such as nets, rope, eel cones, oyster spacers, buoys, crates, and baskets.
Part of the debris is made from plastic pellets, either [[pre-production]] or created from larger plastic items breaking down into smaller pieces. These smaller pieces are referred to as "plastic sand", and now exceed the volume of the beach's natural sand.<ref>[http://www.khnl.com/Global/story.asp?s=7334574 KHNL NBC 8 Honolulu Hawaii |Big Island Beach Attracts Plastic Trash<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Environmental impact== [[Image: Albatross_chick_plastic.jpg|thumb|275px|right|A young bird that was fed plastic by its parents and was unable to eject it, resulting in its death by either starvation or choking.]] [[Wildlife]] in the area has suffered significant damage due to the garbage on- and off-shore. Fishing debris, such as discarded [[fishing net]]s, fishing lines, traps, and strangles, drowns birds and [[sea mammals]]. Birds may die from ingesting large pieces of plastic, especially young birds fed by their parents. [[Sea turtles]] may mistake plastic bags for [[jellyfish]] and choke.<ref>[http://a.abcnews.com/Technology/Story?id=4528488&page=2 ABC News: Landfill in the Sea<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Some types of plastic such as [[bisphenol A]], [[DEHP]], [[phthalates]], and [[styrene]], leech [[carcinogenic]] or poisonous [[chemicals]] when they break down. Others absorb [[toxins]] such as [[DDT]] and [[PCB]]s from their surroundings. These toxins are absorbed by animals when consumed.<ref>[http://honoluluweekly.com/diary/2007/12/sea-of-plastic/ Sea of plastic :: Honolulu Weekly<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Cleanup efforts== At least three major cleanup efforts have taken place on Kamilo Beach in recent years. Prior to the efforts, the debris was 8 to 10 feet high in some places.<ref name=Weiss/> Efforts to clean up marine debris from Kamilo Beach have included those by the Hawai{{okina}}i Wildlife Fund and Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign Hawai{{okina}}i. In February 2006, the Hawai{{okina}}i Wildlife Fund organized 120 volunteers and removed 400 garbage bags of debris and up to 10 tons of fishing nets from the beach.<ref>http://www.pbase.com/charleswilliam3/beach_cleanup&gcmd=add_comment Hawaii Wildlife Fund - South Point Beach Cleanup 2/06 Photo Gallery by CW Lawrence at pbase.com</ref>
In November 2007, Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign Hawai{{okina}}i volunteers removed more than 4 million pieces of plastic from Kamilo Beach.

==History== In ancient times, Kamilo Beach was a location where [[Native Hawaiians]] would go to find large evergreen logs, drifted ashore from the [[Pacific Northwest]], for building [[dug-out]] canoes. It was also a location where those who were lost at sea might eventually wash ashore.<ref name=Dashefsky>{{cite news | last = Dashefsky | first = Howard | title = Big Island Beach Attracts Plastic Trash | work = KHNL NBC 8 Honolulu Hawaii | publisher = ''[[KHNL]]'' | date = 2007-11-09 | url = http://www.khnl.com/Global/story.asp?S=7334574 | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref><ref name=Weiss>{{cite news | last = Weiss | first = Kenneth R. | title = Plague of Plastic Chokes the Seas | work = Part 4: Altered Oceans | publisher = ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' | date = 2007-11-09 | url = http://www.latimes.com/news/local/oceans/la-me-ocean2aug02,0,71579,full.story | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref>
Around 1960, Kamilo Beach was still free of man-made debris, with the exception of a few tires. It was then a place where [[driftwood]], used for sculptures, was gathered by local artists.<ref name=Weiss/>
==Description== [[Image:HIMap-doton-Naalehu.PNG|thumb|250px|right|Location of Kamilo Beach on the island of Hawaii.]] Kamilo Beach is approximately {{convert|1500|ft|m}} long, and is located on the southeast coast of the [[Kau, Hawaii|Ka{{okina}}u District]] on the island of Hawaii.
Kamilo Beach is one of many beaches in the [[Hawaiian Islands]] that receives large amounts of debris from the [[Great Pacific Garbage Patch]]. Also known as ''Plastic Beach'', Kamilo Beach is by far the dirtiest beach in the Hawaiian Islands in terms of amount of debris.<ref>[http://sixtyminutes.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=598914 Seas of Shame<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The [[crescent]]-shaped beach is an accumulation zone for [[plastic]] trash. The debris is forced onto the beach by constant [[Trade wind|trade winds]] and converging [[Ocean current|ocean currents]].
==Debris== The accumulated garbage that covers Kamilo Beach and an adjacent 4.5 kilometers of shoreline consists of 90% plastic.<ref>BBC, Natural World, Message in the Waves - Hawai'i</ref> Although some of the items comprising the trash are household products, the vast majority are fishing related such as nets, rope, eel cones, oyster spacers, buoys, crates, and baskets.
Part of the debris is made from plastic pellets, either [[pre-production]] or created from larger plastic items breaking down into smaller pieces. These smaller pieces are referred to as "plastic sand", and now exceed the volume of the beach's natural sand.<ref>[http://www.khnl.com/Global/story.asp?s=7334574 KHNL NBC 8 Honolulu Hawaii |Big Island Beach Attracts Plastic Trash<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Environmental impact== [[Image: Albatross_chick_plastic.jpg|thumb|275px|right|A young bird that was fed plastic by its parents and was unable to eject it, resulting in its death by either starvation or choking.]] [[Wildlife]] in the area has suffered significant damage due to the garbage on- and off-shore. Fishing debris, such as discarded [[fishing net]]s, fishing lines, traps, and strangles, drowns birds and [[sea mammals]]. Birds may die from ingesting large pieces of plastic, especially young birds fed by their parents. [[Sea turtles]] may mistake plastic bags for [[jellyfish]] and choke.<ref>[http://a.abcnews.com/Technology/Story?id=4528488&page=2 ABC News: Landfill in the Sea<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Some types of plastic such as [[bisphenol A]], [[DEHP]], [[phthalates]], and [[styrene]], leech [[carcinogenic]] or poisonous [[chemicals]] when they break down. Others absorb [[toxins]] such as [[DDT]] and [[PCB]]s from their surroundings. These toxins are absorbed by animals when consumed.<ref>[http://honoluluweekly.com/diary/2007/12/sea-of-plastic/ Sea of plastic :: Honolulu Weekly<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Cleanup efforts== At least three major cleanup efforts have taken place on Kamilo Beach in recent years. Prior to the efforts, the debris was 8 to 10 feet high in some places.<ref name=Weiss/> Efforts to clean up marine debris from Kamilo Beach have included those by the Hawai{{okina}}i Wildlife Fund and Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign Hawai{{okina}}i. In February 2006, the Hawai{{okina}}i Wildlife Fund organized 120 volunteers and removed 400 garbage bags of debris and up to 10 tons of fishing nets from the beach.<ref>http://www.pbase.com/charleswilliam3/beach_cleanup&gcmd=add_comment Hawaii Wildlife Fund - South Point Beach Cleanup 2/06 Photo Gallery by CW Lawrence at pbase.com</ref>
In November 2007, Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign Hawai{{okina}}i volunteers removed more than 4 million pieces of plastic from Kamilo Beach.
