It is known for its accumulation of plastic [[marine debris]] from the [[Great_Pacific_Garbage_Patch|Great Pacific Garbage Patch]].<ref>{{cite news | last = Sarhangi | first = Sheila | title = Getting Trashed | publisher = ''[[Honolulu Magazine]]'' | date = July 2008 | url = http://www.honolulumagazine.com/Honolulu-Magazine/July-2008/Getting-Trashed/ | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref>
==History== In ancient times, Kamilo Beach was a location where [[Native Hawaiians]] would go to find large evergreen logs, drifted ashore from the [[Pacific Northwest]], for building [[dug-out]] canoes. It was also a location where those who were lost at sea might eventually wash ashore.<ref name=Dashefsky>{{cite news | last = Dashefsky | first = Howard | title = Big Island Beach Attracts Plastic Trash | work = KHNL NBC 8 Honolulu Hawaii | publisher = ''[[KHNL]]'' | date = 2007-11-09 | url = http://www.khnl.com/Global/story.asp?S=7334574 | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref><ref name=Weiss>{{cite news | last = Weiss | first = Kenneth R. | title = Plague of Plastic Chokes the Seas | work = Part 4: Altered Oceans | publisher = ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' | date = 2007-11-09 | url = http://www.latimes.com/news/local/oceans/la-me-ocean2aug02,0,71579,full.story | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref>
Around 1960, Kamilo Beach was still free of man-made debris, with the exception of a few tires. It was then a place where [[driftwood]], used for sculptures, was gathered by local artists.<ref name=Weiss/>
==Description== [[Image:HIMap-doton-Naalehu.PNG|thumb|250px|right|Location of Kamilo Beach on the island of Hawaii.]] Kamilo Beach is approximately {{convert|1500|ft|m}} long, and is located on the southeast coast of the [[Kau, Hawaii|Ka{{okina}}u District]] on the island of Hawaii.
Kamilo Beach is one of many beaches in the [[Hawaiian Islands]] that receives large amounts of debris from the [[Great Pacific Garbage Patch]].
The [[crescent]]-shaped beach is an accumulation zone for [[plastic]] trash. The debris is forced onto the beach by constant [[Trade wind|trade winds]] and converging [[Ocean current|ocean currents]].
==Debris== The accumulated garbage that covers Kamilo Beach and an adjacent 2.8 miles (4.5 km) of shoreline consists of 90% plastic.<ref>BBC, Natural World, Message in the Waves - Hawai'i</ref> Although some of the items comprising the trash are household products, the vast majority are fishing related such as nets, rope, eel cones, oyster spacers, buoys, crates, and baskets.
Part of the debris is made from plastic pellets, either [[pre-production]] or created from larger plastic items breaking down into smaller pieces. These smaller pieces are referred to as "plastic sand", and now exceed the volume of the beach's natural sand.<ref name=Dashefsky/>
==Environmental impact== [[Image: Albatross_chick_plastic.jpg|thumb|275px|right|A young bird that was fed plastic by its parents and was unable to eject it, resulting in its death by either starvation or choking.]] [[Wildlife]] in the area has suffered significant damage due to the garbage on- and off-shore. Fishing debris, such as discarded [[fishing net]]s, fishing lines, traps, and strangles, drowns birds and [[sea mammals]]. Birds may die from ingesting large pieces of plastic, especially young birds fed by their parents. [[Sea turtles]] may mistake plastic bags for [[jellyfish]] and choke.<ref name=Rooney>{{cite news | last = Rooney | first = Brian | title = Landfill in the Sea | work = Technology & Science | publisher = ''[[ABC News]]'' | date = 2008-03-26 | url = http://a.abcnews.com/Technology/Story?id=4528488&page=1 | accessdate = 2008-12-06 }}</ref>
Some types of plastic such as [[bisphenol A]], [[DEHP]], [[phthalates]], and [[styrene]], leech [[carcinogenic]] or poisonous [[chemicals]] when they break down. Others absorb [[toxins]] such as [[DDT]] and [[PCB]]s from their surroundings. These toxins are absorbed by animals when consumed.<ref name=McNarie>{{cite news | last = McNarie | first = Alan D. | title = Sea of plastic | publisher = ''[[Honolulu Weekly]]'' | date = 2007-12-05 | url = http://honoluluweekly.com/diary/2007/12/sea-of-plastic/ | accessdate = 2008-12-06 }}</ref>
==Cleanup efforts== At least three major cleanup efforts have taken place on Kamilo Beach in recent years. Prior to the efforts, the debris was {{convert|8|to|10|ft|m}} high in some places.<ref name=Weiss/> Efforts to clean up marine debris from Kamilo Beach have included those by the Hawai{{okina}}i Wildlife Fund and Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign Hawai{{okina}}i. In February 2006, the Hawai{{okina}}i Wildlife Fund organized 120 volunteers and removed 400 garbage bags of debris and up to 10 tons (9 tonnes) of fishing nets from the beach.<ref name=PBase>{{cite web | last = Lawrence | first = Charles | title = Hawaii Wildlife Fund - South Point Beach Cleanup 2/06 | work = Photo gallery | publisher = PBase.com | date = 2006 | url = http://www.pbase.com/charleswilliam3/beach_cleanup | accessdate = 2008-12-06 }}</ref>
In November 2007, Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign Hawai{{okina}}i volunteers removed more than 4 million pieces of plastic from Kamilo Beach.

{{coord|18|54|N|155|40|W|type:city_region:US|display=title}} [[Image:Kamilo_Beach2_Courtesy_Algalita_dot_org.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Kamilo Beach, Hawaii]] '''Kamilo Beach''' (literally, ''the twisting'' in [[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian]]) is a beach located on the southeast coast of the island of [[Hawaii (island)|Hawaii]]. It is known for its accumulation of plastic [[marine debris]] from the [[Great_Pacific_Garbage_Patch|Great Pacific Garbage Patch]].<ref>{{cite news | last = Sarhangi | first = Sheila | title = Getting Trashed | publisher = ''[[Honolulu Magazine]]'' | date = July 2008 | url = http://www.honolulumagazine.com/Honolulu-Magazine/July-2008/Getting-Trashed/ | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref>
==History== In ancient times, Kamilo Beach was a location where [[Native Hawaiians]] would go to find large evergreen logs, drifted ashore from the [[Pacific Northwest]], for building [[dug-out]] canoes. It was also a location where those who were lost at sea might eventually wash ashore.<ref name=Dashefsky>{{cite news | last = Dashefsky | first = Howard | title = Big Island Beach Attracts Plastic Trash | work = KHNL NBC 8 Honolulu Hawaii | publisher = ''[[KHNL]]'' | date = 2007-11-09 | url = http://www.khnl.com/Global/story.asp?S=7334574 | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref><ref name=Weiss>{{cite news | last = Weiss | first = Kenneth R. | title = Plague of Plastic Chokes the Seas | work = Part 4: Altered Oceans | publisher = ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' | date = 2007-11-09 | url = http://www.latimes.com/news/local/oceans/la-me-ocean2aug02,0,71579,full.story | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref>
Around 1960, Kamilo Beach was still free of man-made debris, with the exception of a few tires. It was then a place where [[driftwood]], used for sculptures, was gathered by local artists.<ref name=Weiss/>
==Description== [[Image:HIMap-doton-Naalehu.PNG|thumb|250px|right|Location of Kamilo Beach on the island of Hawaii.]] Kamilo Beach is approximately {{convert|1500|ft|m}} long, and is located on the southeast coast of the [[Kau, Hawaii|Ka{{okina}}u District]] on the island of Hawaii.
Kamilo Beach is one of many beaches in the [[Hawaiian Islands]] that receives large amounts of debris from the [[Great Pacific Garbage Patch]].
The [[crescent]]-shaped beach is an accumulation zone for [[plastic]] trash. The debris is forced onto the beach by constant [[Trade wind|trade winds]] and converging [[Ocean current|ocean currents]].
==Debris== The accumulated garbage that covers Kamilo Beach and an adjacent 2.8 miles (4.5 km) of shoreline consists of 90% plastic.<ref>BBC, Natural World, Message in the Waves - Hawai'i</ref> Although some of the items comprising the trash are household products, the vast majority are fishing related such as nets, rope, eel cones, oyster spacers, buoys, crates, and baskets.
Part of the debris is made from plastic pellets, either [[pre-production]] or created from larger plastic items breaking down into smaller pieces. These smaller pieces are referred to as "plastic sand", and now exceed the volume of the beach's natural sand.<ref name=Dashefsky/>
==Environmental impact== [[Image: Albatross_chick_plastic.jpg|thumb|275px|right|A young bird that was fed plastic by its parents and was unable to eject it, resulting in its death by either starvation or choking.]] [[Wildlife]] in the area has suffered significant damage due to the on- and off-shore garbage. Fishing debris, such as discarded [[fishing net]]s and [[fishing line]]s, [[Drowning|drowns]], [[Strangling|strangles]], and traps birds and [[marine mammal]]s. Birds die from ingesting large pieces of plastic, especially young birds fed by their parents. [[Sea turtles]] may mistake plastic bags for [[jellyfish]] and choke.<ref name=Rooney>{{cite news | last = Rooney | first = Brian | title = Landfill in the Sea | work = Technology & Science | publisher = ''[[ABC News]]'' | date = 2008-03-26 | url = http://a.abcnews.com/Technology/Story?id=4528488&page=1 | accessdate = 2008-12-06 }}</ref>
Some types of plastic and their constituents, such as [[bisphenol A]], [[bis(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate]], and [[polystyrene]], [http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/leach leach] [[carcinogen]]ic or poisonous [[chemical]]s when they [[Biodegradation|break down]]. Others absorb [[toxin]]s such as [[DDT]] and [[polychlorinated biphenyl]]s from their surroundings. These toxins are absorbed by animals when consumed.<ref name=McNarie>{{cite news | last = McNarie | first = Alan D. | title = Sea of plastic | work = [[Honolulu Weekly]] | date = 5 December 2007 | url = http://honoluluweekly.com/diary/2007/12/sea-of-plastic/ | accessdate = 2008-12-06 }}</ref>
==Cleanup efforts== At least three major cleanup efforts have taken place on Kamilo Beach in recent years. Prior to the efforts, the debris was {{convert|8|to|10|ft|m}} high in some places.<ref name=Weiss/> Efforts to clean up marine debris from Kamilo Beach have included those by the Hawai{{okina}}i Wildlife Fund and Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign Hawai{{okina}}i. In February 2006, the Hawai{{okina}}i Wildlife Fund organized 120 volunteers and removed 400 garbage bags of debris and up to 10 tons (9 tonnes) of fishing nets from the beach.<ref name=PBase>{{cite web | last = Lawrence | first = Charles | title = Hawaii Wildlife Fund - South Point Beach Cleanup 2/06 | work = Photo gallery | publisher = PBase.com | date = 2006 | url = http://www.pbase.com/charleswilliam3/beach_cleanup | accessdate = 2008-12-06 }}. See also: {{cite news | last = Smith | first = Dave | title = Try running your toes through this | work = | pages = | publisher = ''[[Hawaii Tribune-Herald]]'' | date = 2006-02-24 | url = http://www.hawaiitribune-herald.com/articles/2006/02/24/local_news/local01.txt | accessdate = }} </ref>
In November 2007, Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign Hawai{{okina}}i volunteers removed more than 4 million pieces of plastic from Kamilo Beach.

{{coord|18|54|N|155|40|W|type:city_region:US|display=title}} [[Image:Kamilo_Beach2_Courtesy_Algalita_dot_org.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Kamilo Beach, Hawaii]] '''Kamilo Beach''' (literally, ''the twisting'' in [[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian]]) is a beach located on the southeast coast of the island of [[Hawaii (island)|Hawaii]]. It is known for its accumulation of plastic [[marine debris]] from the [[Great_Pacific_Garbage_Patch|Great Pacific Garbage Patch]].<ref>{{cite news | last = Sarhangi | first = Sheila | title = Getting Trashed | publisher = ''[[Honolulu Magazine]]'' | date = July 2008 | url = http://www.honolulumagazine.com/Honolulu-Magazine/July-2008/Getting-Trashed/ | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref>
==History== In ancient times, Kamilo Beach was a location where [[Native Hawaiians]] would go to find large [[Pinales|evergreen]] logs, drifted ashore from the [[Pacific Northwest]], for building [[Dugout (boat)#Pacific Islands|dugout canoes]]. It was also a location where those who were lost at sea might eventually wash ashore.<ref name=Dashefsky>{{cite news | last = Dashefsky | first = Howard | title = Big Island Beach Attracts Plastic Trash | work = KHNL NBC 8 Honolulu Hawaii | publisher = ''[[KHNL]]'' | date = 9 November 2007 | url = http://www.khnl.com/Global/story.asp?S=7334574 | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref><ref name=Weiss>{{cite news | last = Weiss | first = Kenneth R. | title = Plague of Plastic Chokes the Seas | work = Part 4: Altered Oceans | publisher = ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' | date = 9 November 2007 | url = http://www.latimes.com/news/local/oceans/la-me-ocean2aug02,0,71579,full.story | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref>
Around 1960, Kamilo Beach was still free of man-made debris, with the exception of a few tires. It was then a place where [[driftwood]], used for sculptures, was gathered by local artists.<ref name=Weiss/>
==Description== [[Image:HIMap-doton-Naalehu.PNG|thumb|250px|right|Location of Kamilo Beach on the island of Hawaii.]] Kamilo Beach is approximately {{convert|1500|ft|m}} long, and is located on the southeast coast of the [[Kau, Hawaii|Ka{{okina}}u District]] on the island of Hawaii.
Kamilo Beach is one of many beaches in the [[Hawaiian Islands]] that receives large amounts of debris from the [[Great Pacific Garbage Patch]].
The [[crescent]]-shaped beach is an accumulation zone for [[plastic]] trash. The debris is forced onto the beach by constant [[Trade wind|trade winds]] and converging [[Ocean current|ocean currents]].
==Debris== The accumulated garbage that covers Kamilo Beach and an adjacent 2.8 miles (4.5 km) of shoreline consists of 90% plastic.<ref>{{cite serial |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0079st6 |network=[[BBC Two]] |title=Natural World |episode=Message in the Waves - Hawai'i}}</ref> Although some of the items comprising the trash are household products, the vast majority are [[fishing]] related such as nets, rope, cones used to trap [[hagfish]], spacers used in [[oyster farming]], [[buoy]]s, crates, and baskets.
Part of the debris is made from plastic pellets, either pre-production [[nurdle]]s or created from larger plastic items breaking down into smaller pieces. These smaller pieces are referred to as "plastic sand", and now exceed the volume of the beach's natural sand.<ref name=Dashefsky/>
==Environmental impact== [[Image: Albatross_chick_plastic.jpg|thumb|275px|right|A young bird that was fed plastic by its parents and was unable to eject it, resulting in its death by either starvation or choking.]] [[Wildlife]] in the area has suffered significant damage due to the on- and off-shore garbage. Fishing debris, such as discarded [[fishing net]]s and [[Fishing line|lines]], [[Drowning|drowns]], [[Strangling|strangles]], and traps birds and [[marine mammal]]s. Birds die from ingesting large pieces of plastic, especially young birds fed by their parents. [[Sea turtles]] may mistake plastic bags for [[jellyfish]] and choke.<ref name=Rooney>{{cite news | last = Rooney | first = Brian | title = Landfill in the Sea | work = Technology & Science | publisher = ''[[ABC News]]'' | date = 2008-03-26 | url = http://a.abcnews.com/Technology/Story?id=4528488&page=1 | accessdate = 2008-12-06 }}</ref>
Some types of plastic and their constituents, such as [[bisphenol A]], [[bis(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate]], and [[polystyrene]], [http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/leach leach] [[carcinogen]]ic or poisonous [[chemical]]s when they [[Biodegradation|break down]]. Others absorb [[toxin]]s such as [[DDT]] and [[polychlorinated biphenyl]]s from their surroundings. These toxins are absorbed by animals when consumed.<ref name=McNarie>{{cite news | last = McNarie | first = Alan D. | title = Sea of plastic | work = [[Honolulu Weekly]] | date = 5 December 2007 | url = http://honoluluweekly.com/diary/2007/12/sea-of-plastic/ | accessdate = 2008-12-06 }}</ref>
==Cleanup efforts== At least three major cleanup efforts have taken place on Kamilo Beach in recent years. Prior to the efforts, the debris was {{convert|8|to|10|ft|m}} high in some places.<ref name=Weiss/> Efforts to clean up marine debris from Kamilo Beach have included those by the Hawai{{okina}}i Wildlife Fund and Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign Hawai{{okina}}i. In February 2006, the Hawai{{okina}}i Wildlife Fund organized 120 volunteers and removed 400 garbage bags of debris and up to 10 tons (9 tonnes) of fishing nets from the beach.<ref name=PBase>{{cite web | last = Lawrence | first = Charles | title = Hawaii Wildlife Fund - South Point Beach Cleanup 2/06 | work = Photo gallery | publisher = PBase.com | date = 2006 | url = http://www.pbase.com/charleswilliam3/beach_cleanup | accessdate = 2008-12-06 }}. See also: {{cite news | last = Smith | first = Dave | title = Try running your toes through this | work = | pages = | publisher = ''[[Hawaii Tribune-Herald]]'' | date = 2006-02-24 | url = http://www.hawaiitribune-herald.com/articles/2006/02/24/local_news/local01.txt | accessdate = }} </ref>
In November 2007, Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign Hawai{{okina}}i volunteers removed more than 4 million pieces of plastic from Kamilo Beach.

==Debris== The accumulated garbage that covers Kamilo Beach and an adjacent 2.8 miles (4.5 km) of shoreline consists of 90% plastic.<ref>{{cite serial |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0079st6 |network=[[BBC Two]] |title=Natural World |episode=Message in the Waves - Hawai'i}}</ref> Although some of the items comprising the trash are household products, the vast majority are [[fishing]] related such as nets, rope, cones used to trap [[hagfish]], spacers used in [[oyster farming]], [[buoy]]s, crates, and baskets.
Part of the debris is made from plastic pellets, either pre-production [[nurdle]]s or created from larger plastic items breaking down into smaller pieces. These smaller pieces are referred to as "plastic sand", and now exceed the volume of the beach's natural sand.<ref name=Dashefsky/>
==Environmental impact== [[Image: Albatross_chick_plastic.jpg|thumb|275px|right|A young bird that was fed plastic by its parents and was unable to eject it, resulting in its death by either starvation or choking.]] [[Wildlife]] in the area has suffered significant damage due to the on- and off-shore garbage. Fishing debris, such as discarded [[fishing net]]s and [[Fishing line|lines]], [[Drowning|drowns]], [[Strangling|strangles]], and traps birds and [[marine mammal]]s. Birds die from ingesting large pieces of plastic, especially young birds fed by their parents. [[Sea turtles]] may mistake plastic bags for [[jellyfish]] and choke.<ref name=Rooney>{{cite news | last = Rooney | first = Brian | title = Landfill in the Sea | work = Technology & Science | publisher = ''[[ABC News]]'' | date = 2008-03-26 | url = http://a.abcnews.com/Technology/Story?id=4528488&page=1 | accessdate = 2008-12-06 }}</ref>
Some types of plastic and their constituents, such as [[bisphenol A]], [[bis(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate]], and [[polystyrene]], [http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/leach leach] [[carcinogen]]ic or poisonous [[chemical]]s when they [[Biodegradation|break down]]. Others absorb [[toxin]]s such as [[DDT]] and [[polychlorinated biphenyl]]s from their surroundings. These toxins are absorbed by animals when consumed.<ref name=McNarie>{{cite news | last = McNarie | first = Alan D. | title = Sea of plastic | work = [[Honolulu Weekly]] | date = 5 December 2007 | url = http://honoluluweekly.com/diary/2007/12/sea-of-plastic/ | accessdate = 2008-12-06 }}</ref>
==Cleanup efforts== At least three major cleanup efforts have taken place on Kamilo Beach in recent years. Prior to the efforts, the debris was {{convert|8|to|10|ft|m}} high in some places.<ref name=Weiss/> Efforts to clean up marine debris from Kamilo Beach have included those by the Hawai{{okina}}i Wildlife Fund and Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign Hawai{{okina}}i. In February 2006, the Hawai{{okina}}i Wildlife Fund organized 120 volunteers and removed 400 garbage bags of debris and up to 10 tons (9 tonnes) of fishing nets from the beach.<ref name=PBase>{{cite web | last = Lawrence | first = Charles | title = Hawaii Wildlife Fund - South Point Beach Cleanup 2/06 | work = Photo gallery | publisher = PBase.com | date = 2006 | url = http://www.pbase.com/charleswilliam3/beach_cleanup | accessdate = 2008-12-06 }} See also: {{cite news | last = Smith | first = Dave | title = Try running your toes through this | work = | pages = | publisher = ''[[Hawaii Tribune-Herald]]'' | date = 2006-02-24 | url = http://www.hawaiitribune-herald.com/articles/2006/02/24/local_news/local01.txt | accessdate = }} </ref>
In November 2007, Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign Hawai{{okina}}i volunteers removed more than 4 million pieces of plastic from Kamilo Beach.

It was also a location where those who were lost at sea might eventually wash ashore.<ref name=Dashefsky>{{cite news | last = Dashefsky | first = Howard | title = Big Island Beach Attracts Plastic Trash | work = KHNL NBC 8 Honolulu Hawaii | publisher = ''[[KHNL]]'' | date = 9 November 2007 | url = http://www.khnl.com/Global/story.asp?S=7334574 | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref><ref name=Weiss>{{cite news | last = Weiss | first = Kenneth R. | title = Plague of Plastic Chokes the Seas | work = Part 4: Altered Oceans | publisher = ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' | date = 9 November 2007 | url = http://www.latimes.com/news/local/oceans/la-me-ocean2aug02,0,71579,full.story | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref>

==Description== [[Image:HIMap-doton-Naalehu.PNG|thumb|Location of Kamilo Beach on the island of Hawaii]] Kamilo Beach is approximately {{convert|1500|ft|m}} long, and is located on the remote southeast coast of the [[Kau, Hawaii|Ka{{okina}} District]] on the island of Hawaii, at coordinates {{coord |18|58|13|N|155|35|59|W| type:landmark_region:US-HI| display=inline,title}}. There are no paved roads to the beach.
Kamilo Beach is one of many beaches in the [[Hawaiian Islands]] that receives large amounts of debris from the [[Great Pacific Garbage Patch]].
The [[crescent]]-shaped beach is an accumulation zone for [[plastic]] trash. The debris is forced onto the beach by constant [[Trade wind|trade winds]] and converging [[Ocean current|ocean currents]].
==Debris== The accumulated garbage that covers Kamilo Beach and an adjacent 2.8 miles (4.5 km) of shoreline consists of 90% plastic.<ref>{{cite serial |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0079st6 |network=[[BBC Two]] |title=Natural World |episode=Message in the Waves - Hawai'i}}</ref> Although some of the items comprising the trash are household products, the vast majority are [[fishing]] related such as nets, rope, cones used to trap [[hagfish]], spacers used in [[oyster farming]], [[buoy]]s, crates, and baskets.
Part of the debris is made from plastic pellets, either pre-production [[nurdle]]s or pellets created from larger plastic items breaking down into smaller pieces. These smaller pieces are referred to as "plastic sand", and now exceed the volume of the beach's natural sand.<ref name=Dashefsky/>
==Environmental impact== [[Image: Albatross_chick_plastic.jpg|thumb|A young bird that was fed plastic by its parents and was unable to eject it, resulting in its death by either starvation or choking]] [[Wildlife]] in the area has suffered significant damage due to the on- and off-shore garbage. Fishing debris, such as discarded [[fishing net]]s and [[Fishing line|lines]], [[Drowning|drowns]], [[Strangling|strangles]], and traps birds and [[marine mammal]]s. Birds die from ingesting large pieces of plastic, especially young birds fed by their parents. [[Sea turtles]] may mistake plastic bags for [[jellyfish]] and choke.<ref name=Rooney>{{cite news | last = Rooney | first = Brian | title = Landfill in the Sea | work = Technology & Science | publisher = ''[[ABC News]]'' | date = 2008-03-26 | url = http://a.abcnews.com/Technology/Story?id=4528488&page=1 | accessdate = 2008-12-06 }}</ref>
Some types of plastic and their constituents, such as [[bisphenol A]], [[bis(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate]], and [[polystyrene]], [http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/leach leach] [[carcinogen]]ic or poisonous [[chemical]]s when they [[Biodegradation|break down]]. Others absorb [[toxin]]s such as [[DDT]] and [[polychlorinated biphenyl]]s from their surroundings. These toxins are absorbed by animals when consumed.<ref name=McNarie>{{cite news | last = McNarie | first = Alan D. | title = Sea of plastic | work = [[Honolulu Weekly]] | date = 5 December 2007 | url = http://honoluluweekly.com/diary/2007/12/sea-of-plastic/ | accessdate = 2008-12-06 }}</ref>
==Cleanup efforts== At least three major cleanup efforts have taken place on Kamilo Beach in recent years. Prior to the efforts, the debris was {{convert|8|to|10|ft|m}} high in some places.<ref name=Weiss/> Efforts to clean up marine debris from Kamilo Beach have included those by the Hawai{{okina}}i Wildlife Fund and Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign Hawai{{okina}}i. In February 2006, the Hawai{{okina}}i Wildlife Fund organized 120 volunteers and removed 400 garbage bags of debris and up to 10 tons (9 tonnes) of fishing nets from the beach.<ref name=PBase>{{cite web | last = Lawrence | first = Charles | title = Hawaii Wildlife Fund - South Point Beach Cleanup 2/06 | work = Photo gallery | publisher = PBase.com | date = 2006 | url = http://www.pbase.com/charleswilliam3/beach_cleanup | accessdate = 2008-12-06 }} See also: {{cite news | last = Smith | first = Dave | title = Try running your toes through this | work = | pages = | publisher = ''[[Hawaii Tribune-Herald]]'' | date = 2006-02-24 | url = http://www.hawaiitribune-herald.com/articles/2006/02/24/local_news/local01.txt | accessdate = }} </ref>
In November 2007, Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign Hawai{{okina}}i volunteers removed more than 4 million pieces of plastic from Kamilo Beach.

[[Image:Kamilo_Beach2_Courtesy_Algalita_dot_org.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Marine debris on Kamilo Beach, Hawaii]] '''Kamilo Beach''' (literally, ''the twisting'' in [[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian]]) is a beach located on the southeast coast of the island of [[Hawaii (island)|Hawaii]]. It is known for its accumulation of plastic [[marine debris]] from the [[Great Pacific Garbage Patch]].<ref>{{cite news | last = Sarhangi | first = Sheila | title = Getting Trashed | publisher = ''[[Honolulu Magazine]]'' | date = July 2008 | url = http://www.honolulumagazine.com/Honolulu-Magazine/July-2008/Getting-Trashed/ | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref>
==History== In ancient times, Kamilo Beach was a location where [[Native Hawaiians]] would go to find large [[Pinales|evergreen]] logs, drifted ashore from the [[Pacific Northwest]], for building [[Dugout (boat)#Pacific Islands|dugout canoes]]. It was also a location where those who were lost at sea might eventually wash ashore.<ref name=Dashefsky>{{cite news | last = Dashefsky | first = Howard | title = Big Island Beach Attracts Plastic Trash | work = KHNL NBC 8 Honolulu Hawaii | publisher = ''[[KHNL]]'' | date = 9 November 2007 | url = http://www.khnl.com/Global/story.asp?S=7334574 | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref><ref name=Weiss>{{cite news | last = Weiss | first = Kenneth R. | title = Plague of Plastic Chokes the Seas | work = Part 4: Altered Oceans | publisher = ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' | date = 9 November 2007 | url = http://www.latimes.com/news/local/oceans/la-me-ocean2aug02,0,71579,full.story | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref>
==Description== [[Image:HIMap-doton-Naalehu.PNG|thumb|Location of Kamilo Beach on the island of Hawaii]] Kamilo Beach is approximately {{convert|1500|ft|m}} long, and is located on the remote southeast coast of the [[Kau, Hawaii|Ka{{okina}} District]] on the island of Hawaii, at coordinates {{coord |18|58|13|N|155|35|59|W| type:landmark_region:US-HI| display=inline,title}}. There are no paved roads to the beach.
Kamilo Beach is one of many beaches in the [[Hawaiian Islands]] that receives large amounts of debris from the [[Great Pacific Garbage Patch]].
The [[crescent]]-shaped beach is an accumulation zone for [[plastic]] trash. The debris is forced onto the beach by constant [[Trade wind|trade winds]] and converging [[Ocean current|ocean currents]].
==Debris== The accumulated garbage that covers Kamilo Beach and an adjacent 2.8 miles (4.5 km) of shoreline consists of 90% plastic.<ref>{{cite serial |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0079st6 |network=[[BBC Two]] |title=Natural World |episode=Message in the Waves - Hawai'i}}</ref> Although some of the items comprising the trash are household products, the vast majority are [[fishing]] related such as nets, rope, cones used to trap [[hagfish]], spacers used in [[oyster farming]], [[buoy]]s, crates, and baskets.
Part of the debris is made from plastic pellets, either pre-production [[nurdle]]s or pellets created from larger plastic items breaking down into smaller pieces. These smaller pieces are referred to as "plastic sand", and now exceed the volume of the beach's natural sand.<ref name=Dashefsky/>
==Environmental impact== [[Image: Albatross_chick_plastic.jpg|thumb|A young bird that was fed plastic by its parents and was unable to eject it, resulting in its death by either starvation or choking]] [[Wildlife]] in the area has suffered significant damage due to the on- and off-shore garbage. Fishing debris, such as discarded [[fishing net]]s and [[Fishing line|lines]], [[Drowning|drowns]], [[Strangling|strangles]], and traps birds and [[marine mammal]]s. Some types of plastic and their constituents, such as [[bisphenol A]], [[bis(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate]], and [[polystyrene]], [http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/leach leach] [[carcinogen]]ic or poisonous [[chemical]]s when they [[Biodegradation|break down]]. Others absorb [[toxin]]s such as [[DDT]] and [[polychlorinated biphenyl]]s from their surroundings. These toxins are absorbed by animals when consumed.<ref name=McNarie>{{cite news | last = McNarie | first = Alan D. | title = Sea of plastic | work = [[Honolulu Weekly]] | date = 5 December 2007 | url = http://honoluluweekly.com/diary/2007/12/sea-of-plastic/ | accessdate = 2008-12-06 }}</ref>
==Cleanup efforts== At least three major cleanup efforts have taken place on Kamilo Beach in recent years. Prior to the efforts, the debris was {{convert|8|to|10|ft|m}} high in some places.<ref name=Weiss/> Efforts to clean up marine debris from Kamilo Beach have included those by the Hawai{{okina}}i Wildlife Fund and Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign Hawai{{okina}}i. In February 2006, the Hawai{{okina}}i Wildlife Fund organized 120 volunteers and removed 400 garbage bags of debris and up to 10 tons (9 tonnes) of fishing nets from the beach.<ref name=PBase>{{cite web | last = Lawrence | first = Charles | title = Hawaii Wildlife Fund - South Point Beach Cleanup 2/06 | work = Photo gallery | publisher = PBase.com | date = 2006 | url = http://www.pbase.com/charleswilliam3/beach_cleanup | accessdate = 2008-12-06 }} See also: {{cite news | last = Smith | first = Dave | title = Try running your toes through this | work = | pages = | publisher = ''[[Hawaii Tribune-Herald]]'' | date = 2006-02-24 | url = http://www.hawaiitribune-herald.com/articles/2006/02/24/local_news/local01.txt | accessdate = }} </ref>
In November 2007, Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign Hawai{{okina}}i volunteers removed more than 4 million pieces of plastic from Kamilo Beach.

K. (1985), ''Beaches of the Big Island'', University of Hawaii Press, ISBN-13: 9780824809768 ISBN-10: 0824809769, p. 69</ref> in [[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian]]), is a beach located on the southeast coast of the island of [[Hawaii (island)|Hawaii]]. It is known for its accumulation of plastic [[marine debris]] from the [[Great Pacific Garbage Patch]].<ref>{{cite news | last = Sarhangi | first = Sheila | title = Getting Trashed | publisher = ''[[Honolulu Magazine]]'' | date = July 2008 | url = http://www.honolulumagazine.com/Honolulu-Magazine/July-2008/Getting-Trashed/ | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref>
==History== In ancient times, Kamilo Beach was a location where [[Native Hawaiians]] would go to find large [[Pinales|evergreen]] logs, drifted ashore from the [[Pacific Northwest]], for building [[Dugout (boat)#Pacific Islands|dugout canoes]]. It was also a location where those who were lost at sea might eventually wash ashore.<ref name=Dashefsky>{{cite news | last = Dashefsky | first = Howard | title = Big Island Beach Attracts Plastic Trash | work = KHNL NBC 8 Honolulu Hawaii | publisher = ''[[KHNL]]'' | date = 9 November 2007 | url = http://www.khnl.com/Global/story.asp?S=7334574 | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref><ref name=Weiss>{{cite news | last = Weiss | first = Kenneth R. | title = Plague of Plastic Chokes the Seas | work = Part 4: Altered Oceans | publisher = ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' | date = 9 November 2007 | url = http://www.latimes.com/news/local/oceans/la-me-ocean2aug02,0,71579,full.story | accessdate = 2008-12-05 }}</ref>
==Description== [[Image:HIMap-doton-Naalehu.PNG|thumb|Location of Kamilo Beach on the island of Hawaii]] Kamilo Beach is approximately {{convert|1500|ft|m}} long, and is located on the remote southeast coast of the [[Kau, Hawaii|Ka{{okina}} District]] on the island of Hawaii, at coordinates {{coord |18|58|13|N|155|35|59|W| type:landmark_region:US-HI| display=inline,title}}. There are no paved roads to the beach.
This beach, situated on a lower lava terrace, is a storm beach. It was formed by the deposit of large amounts of sand blown by prevailing winds.<ref name="Clark-1985-69" />
At the point of Kamilo, waves have cut a large indentation, creating a variety of rocky points, ponds, and channels. Most of these are exposed during low tides, and are awash during high tides.
The debris is situated on the narrow, crescent-shaped strip of white sand, formed along the inland border of this area.<ref name="Clark-1985-69" />
The beach is an accumulation zone for [[plastic]] trash. The debris is forced onto the beach by constant [[Trade wind|trade winds]] and converging [[Ocean current|ocean currents]].
The backshore at Kamilo contains such vegetation as naupaka, milo, and ironweed.<ref name="Clark-1985-69" />
==Debris== The accumulated garbage that covers Kamilo Beach and an adjacent 2.8 miles (4.5 km) of shoreline consists of 90% plastic.<ref>{{cite serial |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0079st6 |network=[[BBC Two]] |title=Natural World |episode=Message in the Waves - Hawai'i}}</ref> Although some of the items comprising the trash are household products, the vast majority are [[fishing]] related such as nets, rope, cones used to trap [[hagfish]], spacers used in [[oyster farming]], [[buoy]]s, crates, and baskets.
Part of the debris is made from plastic pellets, either pre-production [[nurdle]]s or pellets created from larger plastic items breaking down into smaller pieces. These smaller pieces are referred to as "plastic sand", and now exceed the volume of the beach's natural sand.<ref name=Dashefsky/>
==Environmental impact== [[Image: Albatross_chick_plastic.jpg|thumb|A young bird that was fed plastic by its parents and was unable to eject it, resulting in its death by either starvation or choking]] [[Wildlife]] in the area has suffered significant damage due to the on- and off-shore garbage. Fishing debris, such as discarded [[fishing net]]s and [[Fishing line|lines]], [[Drowning|drowns]], [[Strangling|strangles]], and traps birds and [[marine mammal]]s. Some types of plastic and their constituents, such as [[bisphenol A]], [[bis(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate]], and [[polystyrene]], [http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/leach leach] [[carcinogen]]ic or poisonous [[chemical]]s when they [[Biodegradation|break down]]. Others absorb [[toxin]]s such as [[DDT]] and [[polychlorinated biphenyl]]s from their surroundings. These toxins are absorbed by animals when consumed.<ref name=McNarie>{{cite news | last = McNarie | first = Alan D. | title = Sea of plastic | work = [[Honolulu Weekly]] | date = 5 December 2007 | url = http://honoluluweekly.com/diary/2007/12/sea-of-plastic/ | accessdate = 2008-12-06 }}</ref>

==Environmental impact== [[Image:Albatross chick plastic.jpg|thumb|A young bird that was fed plastic by its parents and was unable to eject it, resulting in its death by either starvation or choking]] [[Wildlife]] in the area has suffered significant damage due to the on- and off-shore garbage. Fishing debris, such as discarded [[fishing net]]s and [[Fishing line|lines]], [[Drowning|drowns]], [[Strangling|strangles]], and traps birds and [[marine mammal]]s. Some types of plastic and their constituents, such as [[bisphenol A]], [[bis(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate]], and [[polystyrene]], [http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/leach leach] [[carcinogen]]ic or poisonous [[chemical]]s when they [[Biodegradation|break down]]. Others absorb [[toxin]]s such as [[DDT]] and [[polychlorinated biphenyl]]s from their surroundings. These toxins are absorbed by animals when consumed.<ref name=McNarie>{{cite news | last = McNarie | first = Alan D. | title = Sea of plastic | work = [[Honolulu Weekly]] | date = 5 December 2007 | url = http://honoluluweekly.com/diary/2007/12/sea-of-plastic/ | accessdate = 2008-12-06 }}</ref>
==Cleanup efforts== At least three major cleanup efforts have taken place on Kamilo Beach in recent years. Prior to the efforts, the debris was {{convert|8|to|10|ft|m}} high in some places.<ref name=Weiss/> Efforts to clean up marine debris from Kamilo Beach have included those by the Hawai{{okina}}i Wildlife Fund and Beach Environmental Awareness Campaign Hawai{{okina}}i. In February 2006, the Hawai{{okina}}i Wildlife Fund organized 120 volunteers and removed 400 garbage bags of debris and up to 10 tons (9 tonnes) of fishing nets from the beach.<ref name=PBase>{{cite web | last = Lawrence | first = Charles | title = Hawaii Wildlife Fund - South Point Beach Cleanup 2/06 | work = Photo gallery | publisher = PBase.com | year = 2006 | url = http://www.pbase.com/charleswilliam3/beach_cleanup | accessdate = 2008-12-06 }} See also: {{cite news | last = Smith | first = Dave | title = Try running your toes through this | work = | pages = | publisher = ''[[Hawaii Tribune-Herald]]'' | date = 2006-02-24 | url = http://www.hawaiitribune-herald.com/articles/2006/02/24/local_news/local01.txt | accessdate = }} </ref>

revision.text:
'''Kekaha Kai State Park''', formerly known as '''Kona Coast State Park''', is a located along the North [[Kona District, Hawaii|Kona coast]] on the island of [[Hawaii (island)|Hawai{{okina}}i]]. It includes '''Mahai{{okina}}ula Beach''', '''Makalawena Beach''' and '''Kua Bay'''.
[[Image:Fulica alai.jpg|right|thumb|Hawaiian Coot]] [[Image:Black-necked Stilt.jpg|right|thumb|Hawaiian Stilt]]
The wetland area behind Makalawena beach (the shore of '''Pu{{okina}}u Ali{{okina}}i Bay''')<ref>[http://data.nodc.noaa.gov/coris/data/NOAA/nos/EnvironmentalSensitivityIndices/Hawaii/CDcontents/HI_PDFS/MAPS/HI23.PDF Envrironmental Sensitivity Index Map of Makalawena] on National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration web site</ref> is listed as a [[National Natural Landmark]]. It is known as '''{{okina}}pae{{okina}}ula Pond''' (Hawaiian for "red shrimp"), and was the site of an old fishing village of 7 or 8 houses, wiped out in a 1946 [[tsunami]].<ref>John R. K. [[image:IsaacHalePark3.jpg|thumb|280px|Isaac Hale Beach Park from pier]] '''Isaac Hale Beach Park''', also known as '''Pohoiki''' is an oceanfront park, boat launch and surf location along '''Pohoiki Bay''' in the [[Puna district]] of the [[Hawaii (island)|Big Island of Hawaii]]. It is only one of a few places in the Southeast shore of Hawaii that allows for such facilities. Pohoiki Bay is known for its strong currents and although the park is known for good snorkeling, conditions are usually not ideal. The park was expanded and modernized in 2006.<ref>http://www.hawaii-county.com/parks/isaachale.htm County of Hawaii Parks and Recreation</ref>
It is located at the intersection narrow Pohoiki road and the Kapoho-Kalapana road (Hawaii state route 137), coordinates {{coord |19|27|27|N| 154|50|28|W|type:landmark_region:US-HI| display=inline,title}}.

It is only one of a few places in the Southeast shore of Hawaii that allows for such facilities. The park is named in honor of Private Isaac K. Hale. During the Korean War, Hale served in the United States Army's 19th Infantry Regiment, 24th Infantry Division. He was killed in action north of the 38th parallel on July 12, 1951.

[[Image:Anaehoomalu Bay Aerial.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Aerial view of Waikoloa Beach and the Ku{{okina}}uali{{okina}}i and Kahapapa Fishponds]]]] Waikoloa Beach is an area located on the [[Kohala, Hawaii|South Kohala]] coast on the island of [[Hawaii (island)|Hawaii]] and is located in the [[census-designated place]] of [[Puako, Hawaii|Puako]]. It can be confused for [[Waikoloa Village]], a CDP in the same "[[ahupuaa]]".<ref>[http://waikoloabeachresort.com/Waikoloa-Beach-Resort Official Web site for the Waikoloa Beach Resort]</ref>
The area is home to many notable cultural and geologic features of the ancient [[Hawaiian culture]] including [[aquaculture]] fishponds, [[anchialine]] ponds and [[petroglyphs]].
==Ala Kahakai== Ala Kahakai or trail by the sea is the name for the ancient pathway that runs along the coastline in the Waikoloa area that linked important entities in the Hawaiian culture including communities, temples, fishing areas, etc. The Wikoloa Ala Kahakai, estimated to be 175 miles long, is commonly called Kings Trail".
==Anaehoomalu Bay== [[Anaehoomalu Bay]] is the prominent bay of Waikoloa Beach and is south of the Waikoloa Resort area.
==Anchialine Ponds== The anchialine ponds of Waikoloa were part of Hawaiian culture and were preserved in 1985 as the '''Waikoloa Anchialine Pond Preservation Area''' maintained by the [[University of Hawaii]]. The brackish water lava pools located just at the coastline are fed by both freshwater springs from rain water and sea water making the ponds a unique [[microclimate]] suitable for a various small fishes, crustaceans, mollusks and tiny red shrimps.
==Ku{{okina}}uali{{okina}}i and Kahapapa Fishponds== The Ku{{okina}}uali{{okina}}i and Kahapapa Fishponds are located just behind the Waikoloa Beach in Anaeho{{okina}}omalu bay. Historically, it is understood that Anaehoomalu was a center of thriving aquaculture. The two ponds were part of complex of fish farms, carefully tended by ancient Hawaiian people.
==Hilton Waikoloa Village== The Hilton Waikoloa Village is built on 62 acres and has 1240 rooms and suites with tropical gardens, waterfalls, lagoons and waterways, awaiting your arrival by the hotels exclusive tram or boat. The Hilton Waikoloa Village recently unveiled the new Dolphin Quest Village.
==Petroglyphs== There are many historically significant petroglyphs or stone carvings in the Waikoloa. There are potetially the closest thing to a written language that Hawaiians used. The petroglyphs are thought to be [[astronomical symbols]].

[[Image:Anaehoomalu Bay Aerial.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Aerial view of Waikoloa Beach and the Ku{{okina}}uali{{okina}}i and Kahapapa Fishponds]] Waikoloa Beach is an area located on the [[Kohala, Hawaii|South Kohala]] coast on the island of [[Hawaii (island)|Hawaii]] and is located in the [[census-designated place]] of [[Puako, Hawaii|Puako]]. It can be confused for [[Waikoloa Village]], a CDP in the same "[[ahupuaa]]".<ref>[http://waikoloabeachresort.com/Waikoloa-Beach-Resort Official Web site for the Waikoloa Beach Resort]</ref>
The area is home to many notable cultural and geologic features of the ancient [[Hawaiian culture]] including [[aquaculture]] fishponds, [[anchialine]] ponds and [[petroglyphs]].
==Ala Kahakai== Ala Kahakai or trail by the sea is the name for the ancient pathway that runs along the coastline in the Waikoloa area that linked important entities in the Hawaiian culture including communities, temples, fishing areas, etc. The Wikoloa Ala Kahakai, estimated to be 175 miles long, is commonly called Kings Trail".
==Anaehoomalu Bay== [[Anaehoomalu Bay]] is the prominent bay of Waikoloa Beach and is south of the Waikoloa Resort area.
==Anchialine Ponds== The anchialine ponds of Waikoloa were part of Hawaiian culture and were preserved in 1985 as the '''Waikoloa Anchialine Pond Preservation Area''' maintained by the [[University of Hawaii]]. The brackish water lava pools located just at the coastline are fed by both freshwater springs from rain water and sea water making the ponds a unique [[microclimate]] suitable for a various small fishes, crustaceans, mollusks and tiny red shrimps.
==Ku{{okina}}uali{{okina}}i and Kahapapa Fishponds== The Ku{{okina}}uali{{okina}}i and Kahapapa Fishponds are located just behind the Waikoloa Beach in Anaeho{{okina}}omalu bay. Historically, it is understood that Anaehoomalu was a center of thriving aquaculture. The two ponds were part of complex of fish farms, carefully tended by ancient Hawaiian people.
==Hilton Waikoloa Village== The Hilton Waikoloa Village is built on 62 acres and has 1240 rooms and suites with tropical gardens, waterfalls, lagoons and waterways, awaiting your arrival by the hotels exclusive tram or boat. The Hilton Waikoloa Village recently unveiled the new Dolphin Quest Village.
==Petroglyphs== There are many historically significant petroglyphs or stone carvings in the Waikoloa. There are potetially the closest thing to a written language that Hawaiians used. The petroglyphs are thought to be [[astronomical symbols]].

revision.text:
'''Kauna{{okina}}oa Bay''' has one of the few white sand beaches of the [[Kohala Coast]], the western side of the [[Hawaii (island)|island of Hawai{{okina}}i]]. The historic [[Mauna Kea Beach Hotel]] is located on the bay.
==Description== The bay is accessed via Mauna Kea Beach Drive, just west of state Route 19, [[Hawaii Belt Road]], at {{coord| 20|0|16|N| 155|49|30|W| display=inline,title |type:landmark_region:US-HI}}, about {{convert|2.6|mi}} south of [[Kawaihae, Hawaii]]. A part of the [[Ala Kahakai National Historic Trail]] can be hiked north to [[ Samuel M. Spencer Beach Park]] or south to [[Hapuna Beach State Recreation Area]]. Although public restrooms and showers are available, a limited number of parking passes are available at the resort gate.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.co.hawaii.hi.us/planning/spa/south_kohala/map2.html |title= South Kohala map 2 |work=Shoreline access |publisher=on official Hawai{{okina}}i County web site |accessdate=2010-03-30 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
'''Kauna{{okina}}oa Bay''' has one of the few white sand beaches of the [[Kohala Coast]], the western side of the [[Hawaii (island)|island of Hawai{{okina}}i]]. A historic hotel is located on the bay, which has given it the name '''Mauna Kea Beach'''.
==Description== The bay is accessed via Mauna Kea Beach Drive, just west of state Route 19, [[Hawaii Belt Road]], at {{coord| 20|0|16|N| 155|49|30|W| display=inline,title |type:landmark_region:US-HI}}, about {{convert|2.6|mi}} south of [[Kawaihae, Hawaii]].<ref>{{gnis|1905422|Kaunaoa Bay}}</ref> A part of the [[Ala Kahakai National Historic Trail]] can be hiked north to [[Samuel M. Spencer Beach Park]] or south to [[Hapuna Beach State Recreation Area]]. Although public restrooms and showers are available, a limited number of parking passes are available at the resort gate.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.co.hawaii.hi.us/planning/spa/south_kohala/map2.html |title= South Kohala map 2 |work=Shoreline access |publisher=on official Hawai{{okina}}i County web site |accessdate=2010-03-30 }}</ref> The beach was named "America's Best Beach" in 2000 by [[Florida International University]] professor [[Stephen Leatherman]].<ref>{{cite web |title= America's Best Beaches |work= DrBeach.Org web site |author= Stephen P. Leatherman |url= http://www.drbeach.org/drbeach |accessdate= 2010-04-02 }}</ref>
==History== The land above the bay is part of the [[Parker Ranch]]. In 1965 ranch owner [[Richard Smart (actor)|Richard Smart]] leased it for a hotel financed by [[Laurance Rockefeller]].<ref name="trust">{{cite web |title= Richard Paler Smart: Founder |publisher= Parker Ranch Foundation Trust |url= http://prft.org/index.php/prft/RICHARD_PALMER_SMART |accessdate= 2010-04-02 }}</ref> It is named [[Mauna Kea Beach Hotel]] for the mountain [[Mauna Kea]] which is visible above the bay when not obscured by clouds.<ref>{{cite news |title= Grande dame back in all her glitter |date= March 29, 2009 |newspaper= [[West Hawaii Today]] |author= Chelsea Jensen |url= http://www.westhawaiitoday.com/articles/2009/03/29/local/local01.txt |accessdate= 2010-04-02 }}</ref> Before development [[hawksbill turtle]]s nested on the beach. In 1973 a lawsuit was filed to allow public access to the beach. An agreement was finally reached after seven years of litigation. A small number of parking spaces were made available starting in 1981, and trails opened up along the shoreline.<ref>{{cite book |author=John R. K. Clark |chapter= (76) Kauna{{okina}}oa |pages= 134135 |title= Beaches of the Big Island |publisher= University of Hawaii Press |year= 1985 |isbn= 978-0824809768 |url= http://books.google.com/books?id=ligZzOytgK4C }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

Leatherman |url= http://www.drbeach.org/drbeach |accessdate= 2010-04-02 }}</ref>
==History== The land above the bay is part of the [[Parker Ranch]]. In 1960 the area was a remote, barren, hot lava field unsuitable for cattle grazing. [[William F. Quinn]], the governor of the new state of [[Hawaii]], invited [[Laurance Rockefeller]] to visit the islands as part of a study for a federal commission that Rockefeller chaired. After visiting the ranch, Rockefeller was taken for a swim in the bay. Plans for a resort began in January 1961. The state agreed to pave the [[Hawaii Belt Road]] (called the Queen [[Kaahumanu|Ka{{okina}}ahumanu]] highway) to the site and build a new [[Kona International Airport]]. Rockefeller bought the land of the nearby [[Pu'ukohola Heiau National Historic Site|Pu{{okina}}ukohol Heiau]] and donated it for a National Historic Park.<ref name="paradise"/>
The open-air design allowed natural ventilation from the [[trade winds]], although rooms had air conditioning available. The hotel finally opened in July 1965, one of the most expensive at the time. Hotels with similar designs would be built along the Kohala coast over the next decades.<ref name="paradise">{{cite book |author1=Don Hibbard|author2=Augie Salbosa|title=Designing paradise: the allure of the Hawaiian resort |chapter= Where God Left Off: The Diamond Tiara of Laurance Rockerfeller and a Polynesian Village |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=REJB-dhBLQsC&pg=PA101 |year=2006 |publisher=Princeton Architectural Press |isbn=9781568985749 |pages=101112 }}</ref> Ranch owner [[Richard Smart (actor)|Richard Smart]] negotiated a long term lease of the land.<ref name="trust">{{cite web |title= Richard Paler Smart: Founder |publisher= Parker Ranch Foundation Trust |url= http://prft.org/index.php/prft/RICHARD_PALMER_SMART |accessdate= 2010-04-02 }}</ref> The hotel was named [[Mauna Kea Beach Hotel]] for the mountain [[Mauna Kea]] which is visible above the bay when not obscured by clouds.<ref>{{cite news |title= Grande dame back in all her glitter |date= March 29, 2009 |newspaper= [[West Hawaii Today]] |author= Chelsea Jensen |url= http://www.westhawaiitoday.com/articles/2009/03/29/local/local01.txt |accessdate= 2010-04-02 }}</ref>
Before development [[hawksbill turtle]]s nested on the beach. In 1973 a lawsuit was filed to allow public access to the beach. An agreement was finally reached after seven years of litigation. A small number of parking spaces were made available starting in 1981, and trails opened up along the shoreline.<ref>{{cite book |author=John R. K. Clark |chapter= (76) Kauna{{okina}}oa |pages= 134135 |title= Beaches of the Big Island |publisher= University of Hawaii Press |year= 1985 |isbn= 978-0824809768 |url= http://books.google.com/books?id=ligZzOytgK4C }}</ref>

==Description== The bay is accessed via Mauna Kea Beach Drive, just west of state Route 19, [[Hawaii Belt Road]], at {{coord| 20|0|16|N| 155|49|30|W| display=inline,title |type:landmark_region:US-HI}}, about {{convert|2.6|mi}} south of [[Kawaihae, Hawaii]].<ref>{{gnis|1905422|Kaunaoa Bay}}</ref> A part of the [[Ala Kahakai National Historic Trail]] can be hiked north to [[Samuel M. Spencer Beach Park]] or south to [[Hapuna Beach State Recreation Area]]. Although public restrooms and showers are available, a limited number of parking passes are available at the resort gate.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.co.hawaii.hi.us/planning/spa/south_kohala/map2.html |title= South Kohala map 2 |work=Shoreline access |publisher=on official Hawai{{okina}}i County web site |accessdate=2010-03-30 }}</ref> The beach was named "America's Best Beach" in 2000 by [[Florida International University]] professor [[Stephen Leatherman]].<ref>{{cite web |title= America's Best Beaches |work= DrBeach.Org web site |author= Stephen P. Leatherman |url= http://www.drbeach.org/drbeach |accessdate= 2010-04-02 }}</ref>
==History== The land above the bay is part of the [[Parker Ranch]]. In 1960 the area was a remote, barren, hot lava field unsuitable for cattle grazing. [[William F. Quinn]], the governor of the new state of [[Hawaii]], invited [[Laurance Rockefeller]] to visit the islands as part of a study for a federal commission that Rockefeller chaired. After visiting the ranch, Rockefeller was taken for a swim in the bay. Plans for a resort began in January 1961. The state agreed to pave the [[Hawaii Belt Road]] (called the Queen [[Kaahumanu|Ka{{okina}}ahumanu]] highway for this section) to the site and build a new [[Kona International Airport]]. Rockefeller bought the land of the nearby [[Pu'ukohola Heiau National Historic Site|Pu{{okina}}ukohol Heiau]] and donated it for a National Historic Park.<ref name="paradise"/>
The open-air design allowed natural ventilation from the [[trade winds]], although rooms had air conditioning available. The hotel finally opened in July 1965, one of the most expensive at the time. Hotels with similar designs would be built along the Kohala coast over the next decades.<ref name="paradise">{{cite book |author1=Don Hibbard|author2=Augie Salbosa|title=Designing paradise: the allure of the Hawaiian resort |chapter= Where God Left Off: The Diamond Tiara of Laurance Rockerfeller and a Polynesian Village |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=REJB-dhBLQsC&pg=PA101 |year=2006 |publisher=Princeton Architectural Press |isbn=9781568985749 |pages=101112 }}</ref> Ranch owner [[Richard Smart (actor)|Richard Smart]] negotiated a long term lease of the land.<ref name="trust">{{cite web |title= Richard Paler Smart: Founder |publisher= Parker Ranch Foundation Trust |url= http://prft.org/index.php/prft/RICHARD_PALMER_SMART |accessdate= 2010-04-02 }}</ref> The hotel was named [[Mauna Kea Beach Hotel]] for the mountain [[Mauna Kea]] which is visible above the bay when not obscured by clouds.<ref name="dame">{{cite news |title= Grande dame back in all her glitter |date= March 29, 2009 |newspaper= [[West Hawaii Today]] |author= Chelsea Jensen |url= http://www.westhawaiitoday.com/articles/2009/03/29/local/local01.txt |accessdate= 2010-04-02 }}</ref>
Before development [[hawksbill turtle]]s nested on the beach. In 1973 a lawsuit was filed to allow public access to the beach. An agreement was finally reached after seven years of litigation. A small number of parking spaces were made available starting in 1981, and trails opened up along the shoreline.<ref>{{cite book |author=John R. K. Clark |chapter= (76) Kauna{{okina}}oa |pages= 134135 |title= Beaches of the Big Island |publisher= University of Hawaii Press |year= 1985 |isbn= 978-0824809768 |url= http://books.google.com/books?id=ligZzOytgK4C }}</ref>
The bay was only a few miles from the [[2006 Hawaii earthquake]] which damaged the hotel.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eqinthenews/2006/ustwbh | date = 2006-10-15 | title = Magnitude 6.7 - Hawaii region, Hawaii | accessdate = 2010-04-05 | publisher = [[United States Geological Survey|USGS]] }}</ref> The hotel reopened in early 2009.<ref name="dame"/>

Before development [[hawksbill turtle]]s nested on the beach. In 1973 a lawsuit was filed to allow public access to the beach. An agreement was finally reached after seven years of litigation. A small number of parking spaces were made available starting in 1981, and trails opened up along the shoreline.<ref>{{cite book |author=John R. K. Clark |chapter= (76) Kauna{{okina}}oa |pages= 134135 |title= Beaches of the Big Island |publisher= University of Hawaii Press |year= 1985 |isbn= 978-0824809768 |url= http://books.google.com/books?id=ligZzOytgK4C }}</ref>
The bay was only a few miles from the [[2006 Hawaii earthquake]] which damaged the hotel.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eqinthenews/2006/ustwbh | date = 2006-10-15 | title = Magnitude 6.7 - Hawaii region, Hawaii | accessdate = 2010-04-05 | publisher = [[United States Geological Survey|USGS]] }}</ref> The hotel reopened in early 2009.<ref name="dame"/>
